Note: The words “has gone” are understood. People’s wailing and others hearing it is spoken of as if the wailing had gone as far away as these two places. Alternate translation: “the wailing has gone as far as Egalim and Beer Elim” or “people even as far away as Elaim and Beer Elim wail”

Quote: Eglaim & Beer Elim
Note: These are names of cities and towns. Dimon was the principal city of the country of Moab. Several modern versions have “Dibon” instead of “Dimon.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: Dimon
Note: This is the name of a city or town. Dimon was the principal city of the country of Moab. Several modern versions have “Dibon” instead of “Dimon.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: but I will bring even more upon Dimon
Note: Here “I” refers to Yahweh. Also, “Dimon” refers to the people who live there. Alternate translation: “but I will cause even more trouble for the people of Dimon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

# Isaiah 16 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

This chapter is a continuation of the previous chapter and is a prophecy against the nation of Moab. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]])

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in 16:1-12.

Quote: Send rams to the ruler of the land
Note: The Moabites will send rams to the king of Judah so that he might protect them from the enemy army. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

Quote: Selah
Note: This is the name of a city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: the daughter of Zion
Note: The “daughter” of a city means the people of the city. See how you translated this in [Isaiah 1:8](../01/08.md). Alternate translation: “the people of Zion” or “the people who live in Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: As wandering birds, as a scattered nest, so the women of Moab are at the fords of the Arnon River
Note: All the people of Moab, which includes the women, are forced to flee from their homes. Alternate translation: “Like birds without a home, the women of Moab will flee across the river to another land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: As wandering birds, as a scattered nest
Note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: provide some shade like night in the middle of the day
Note: The heat of the middle of the day represents the Moabites’ suffering from their enemies, and shade represents protection from their enemies. Comparing the shade to night shows that they want strong protection. Alternate translation: “protect us completely from our enemies as a large shadow protects people from the hot sun” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: Let them live among you, the refugees from Moab
Note: “Allow the refugees from Moab to live with you.” Here “you” refers to the people of Judah.

Quote: be a hiding place for them from the destroyer
Note: Providing a hiding place is spoken of as being a hiding place. Alternate translation: “give them a place to hide from those who are trying to destroy them” or “hide them from those who want to destroy them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: A throne will be established in covenant faithfulness
Note: Here “throne” refers to the power to rule as king. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “faithful.” If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will be faithful to the covenant and he will appoint a king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: one from David’s tent will faithfully sit there
Note: Here “David’s tent” represents David’s family, including his descendants. Sitting on the throne represents ruling. Alternate translation: “a descendant of David will rule faithfully” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: as he seeks justice
Note: Seeking justice represents wanting to do what is just. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: We have heard of Moab’s pride, his arrogance, his boasting, and his anger
Note: The words “Moab’s” and “his” refer to the people of Moab. Alternate translation: “We have heard that the people of Moab are proud and arrogant, boastful and angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: We have heard
Note: Possible meanings are that: (1) Isaiah is speaking and “We” refers to him and the people of Judah, or (2) God is speaking and “We” refers to God.

Quote: But his boastings are empty words
Note: Alternate translation: “But what they say about themselves means nothing” or “But what they boast about is not true”

Quote: So Moab wails for Moab—they all wail
Note: “Moab” represents the people of Moab. “So all the people of Moab will cry out loud over what has happened to their cities” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: for the raisin cakes of Kir Hareseth
Note: Alternate translation: “because there are no raisin cakes in Kir Hareseth”

Quote: raisin cakes
Note: The Hebrew word used here means either “raisin cakes” or “men.”

Quote: Kir Hareseth
Note: “Kir Hareseth” is the name of a city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: Heshbon
Note: Translate the name of this city as you did in [Isaiah 15:4](../15/04.md).

Quote: Sibmah & Jazer
Note: These are names of cities. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: The rulers of the nations have trampled the choice vines
Note: The land of Moab was known for its vineyards. Here God describes the land of Moab as one large vineyard. This emphasizes that the rulers, which refers to the armies, completely destroyed everything in Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Indeed I will weep
Note: In 16:9-10 the word “I” refers to Yahweh.

Quote: I will water you with my tears
Note: God speaks of his deep sorrow for these places as if he would cry much and his many tears would fall on them. Alternate translation: “I will cry much for you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Jazer & Sibmah
Note: Translate the names of these cities as you did in [Isaiah 16:8](../16/08.md).

Quote: Heshbon & Elealeh
Note: Translate the names of these cities as you did in [Isaiah 15:4](../15/04.md).

Quote: For on your fields of summer fruits and harvest I have ended the shouts of joy
Note: The “shouts of joy” represent people shouting for joy about the harvest of their fruit trees. Alternate translation: “Because of what I will do, you will no longer shout for joy when you harvest your fields of summer fruit” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: I have put an end to the shouts of the one who treads
Note: Here “the shouts” refers to the joy of the people who tread the grapes to produce the wine. Alternate translation: “therefore the people who tread the grapes do not shout with joy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: So my heart sighs like a harp for Moab
Note: The phrase “my heart” represents Yahweh and his sad feelings. He compares his sigh to the sound of a sad song played on a harp. Alternate translation: “So I sigh like a sad song on a harp” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: Moab
Note: This refer to the people of Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: my inward being for Kir Hareseth
Note: The phrase “my inward being” represents Yahweh. The word “sighs” is understood from the previous phrase. See how you translated Kir Hareseth in [Isaiah 16:7](../16/07.md). Alternate translation: “my inward being sighs for Kir Hareseth” or “I am very sad for the people of Kir Hareseth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: Kir Hareseth
Note: This is a metonym for the people of the city. Alternate translation: “the people of Kir Hareseth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Moab & himself & his
Note: All of these words refer to the people of Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: his prayers will accomplish nothing
Note: Alternate translation: “his prayers will not be answered”

Quote: This is the word
Note: “This is the message.” This refers to all he said in 15:1-16:12.

Quote: concerning Moab
Note: The word “Moab” refers to the people of Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: the glory of Moab will disappear
Note: Alternate translation: “The country of Moab will no longer be glorious”

# Isaiah 17 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

The ULT sets the lines in 17:1-6, 9-14 farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text because they are part of a long quotation.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Damascus
This chapter prophesies destruction against the people of Damascus. Damascus was the capital of Aram. The people of Damascus worship gods other than Yahweh and have fought Yahweh’s people. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]], [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/falsegod]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/peopleofgod]])

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### Ephraim
This chapter prophesied destruction against the kingdom of Israel. They are also called Ephraim in this chapter. Both the northern kingdom of Israel and Aram were conquered at about the same time in history.

Quote: about Damascus
Note: Damascus is the name of a city. See how you translated this in [Isaiah 7:8](../07/08.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: The cities of Aroer will be abandoned
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. “All the people will abandon the cities of Aroer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: no one will frighten them
Note: The word “them” refers to the sheep.

Quote: Fortified cities will disappear from Ephraim
Note: Ephraim was the largest tribe in Israel. Here it represents the entire northern kingdom of Israel. Alternate translation: “Strong cities will disappear from Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: will disappear
Note: This does not mean that they will vanish, but that the cities will be destroyed.

Quote: the kingdom from Damascus
Note: The words “will disappear” are understood from the previous phrase. Damascus was where the king of Aram ruled from. The kingdom disappearing represents the king no longer having royal power. Alternate translation: “the kingdom will disappear from Damascus” or “there will be no royal power in Damascus” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: this is the declaration of Yahweh of hosts
Note: Yahweh speaks of himself by name to express the certainty of what he is declaring. Translate as in [Isaiah 14:22](../14/22.md). Alternate translation: “this is what Yahweh of hosts has declared” or “this is what I, Yahweh of hosts, have declared” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

Quote: It will come about
Note: This phrase is used here to mark an important event that will happen. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.

Quote: the glory of Jacob will become thin, and the fatness of his flesh will become lean
Note: Here “Jacob” refers to the kingdom of Israel. Israel would no longer be glorious. Rather it would be weak and poor. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: It will be as when a harvester gathers the standing grain & in the Valley of Rephaim
Note: There will be nothing left in the land after God punishes the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: the Valley of Rephaim
Note: This is a valley where people normally grew and harvested much food. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: Gleanings will be left
Note: The word “Gleanings” here represents the people who will still live in Israel. Alternate translation: “But there will be a few people left in Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: as when the olive tree is shaken
Note: People harvested olive trees by shaking them so that the olives would fall out. Alternate translation: “like the few olives that remain on the olive trees after people harvest them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: four or five
Note: The word “olives” is understood from the phrase before this. Alternate translation: “four or five olives” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: this is the declaration of Yahweh, the God of Israel
Note: Yahweh speaks of himself by name to express the certainty of what he is declaring. Alternate translation: “this is what Yahweh, the God of Israel, has declared” or “this is what I, Yahweh, the God of Israel, have declared” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

Quote: men will look toward their Maker & will look to the Holy One of Israel
Note: Looking toward God here represents hoping that he will help them. Alternate translation: “men will hope that their Maker, the Holy One of Israel, will help them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: men will look
Note: The word “men” represents people in general. Alternate translation: “people will look” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: their eyes will look
Note: Here “eyes” represents the people who look. Alternate translation: “they will look” or “the people will look” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: Holy One of Israel
Note: See how you translated this in [Isaiah 1:4](../01/04.md).

Quote: They will not look to the altars
Note: Looking to the altars represents worshiping idols with the hope that the idols will help them. Alternate translation: “They will not worship idols at their altars” or “The people of Israel will not go to their altars and ask their idols to help them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: the work of their hands
Note: Here the people are represented by their “hands” to emphasize that they made the altars or idols. Alternate translation: “that they made with their hands” or “which they themselves built” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: what their fingers have made & the Asherah poles or the sun images
Note: The second phrase identifies the things that the people made. Speaking of the fingers here emphasizes that the people made them, so these things are not real gods. Alternate translation: “the Asherah poles or the sun images, which they themselves made” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: that were forsaken because of the people of Israel
Note: It can be made explicit who left these lands. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “that the Hivites and Amorites left after the people of Israel came” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: For you have forgotten
Note: Here “you” refers to the people of Israel. The word “forgotten” does not mean they have no memory of God. It means they no longer obey him. Alternate translation: “For you no longer obey”

Quote: the God of your salvation
Note: Alternate translation: “the God who saves you”

Quote: have ignored the rock of your strength
Note: This compares God to a large rock which people could climb on to get away from their enemies or hide behind. Alternate translation: “have ignored God, who is like a rock that protects you” or “have ignored the one who protects you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the harvest will fail
Note: Alternate translation: “there will not be much fruit for you to harvest”

Quote: The uproar of many peoples, that roar like the roaring of the seas
Note: An uproar is a very loud noise. Alternate translation: “The sound of many people, that is very loud like the seas” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: the rushing of nations, that rush like the rushing of mighty waters
Note: The enemy armies appear to be a powerful force that no one can stop. Alternate translation: “the nations come rushing in like the mighty waters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: the rushing of nations
Note: The word “nations” refers to the armies of those nations. Alternate translation: “the rushing of the enemy armies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: before the wind like chaff on the mountains & like weeds whirling before a storm
Note: These two phrases mean the same thing. The enemy armies seem powerful but God will easily stop them and send them away. Alternate translation: “like chaff on the mountains that the wind blows away … like weeds that whirl and blow away as a storm approaches” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: This is the portion of those
Note: What happens to them is spoken of as if it is a portion that they inherit. Alternate translation: “This is what happens to those” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: loot us & rob us
Note: The word “us” refers to Isaiah and the people of Judah.

# Isaiah 18 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Cush
This chapter records prophecies against the nation of Cush. They are being punished by Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Metaphors
This chapter uses many metaphors to describe the destruction coming to the people of Cush. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Woe to the land of the rustling of wings, which is along the rivers of Cush
Note: Here, the phrase **the rustling of wings** could mean (1) the boats that have sails are spoken of as having wings. Alternate translation: “Woe to those who live in the land beyond the rivers of Cush, whose many ships look like insects on the water” or (2) the rustling of wings refers to the noise of insects that have wings, perhaps locusts. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: by the sea
Note: The Nile River was very wide, and people in Egypt and Cush referred to it as “the sea.” Alternate translation: “on the great river” or “along the Nile River” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: vessels of papyrus
Note: Papyrus is a tall plant that grows along the side of the Nile River. People bound together papyrus bundles to make boats. Alternate translation: “papyrus boats” or “boats made of reeds” or (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

Quote: a nation tall and smooth & a people feared far and near & a nation strong and trampling down, whose land the rivers divide
Note: These phrases all describe the people of one nation.

Quote: a nation tall and smooth
Note: The word “nation” here refers to the people of that nation. Alternate translation: “a nation whose people are tall and have smooth skin” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: a people feared far and near
Note: The words “far” and “near” are used together to mean “everywhere.” Alternate translation: “a people who are feared everywhere” or “a people that everyone in the earth fears” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

Quote: a nation strong and trampling down
Note: Trampling down represents conquering other nations. Alternate translation: “a nation that is strong and conquers other nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: the rivers divide
Note: This probably refers to many rivers that flow through the nation so they divide it into different parts.

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nVerse 3 tells what the messengers in [Isaiah 18:2](../18/02.md) must say to the people of the world.

Quote: All you inhabitants of the world & you who live on the earth
Note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: “All you people on the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: when a signal is lifted up on the mountains, look; and when the trumpet is blown, listen
Note: The signal and trumpet were to call people to battle. The commands to look and listen are commands to pay attention and prepare for battle. Alternate translation: “pay attention when the signal is lifted up on the mountains and the trumpet is blown”

Quote: when a signal is lifted up on the mountains, look
Note: The signal was a flag used to call people to battle. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “pay attention when you see the battle flag on the mountains” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: when the trumpet is blown, listen
Note: The trumpets were used to call people to battle. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “pay attention when you hear the sound of the battle trumpets” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: General Information:
Note: # General Information:\n\nGod uses a parable about a farmer in a vineyard in order to describe how he will punish a certain nation. That nation is either Ethiopia or Ethiopia’s enemy.

Quote: This is what Yahweh said to me
Note: “Yahweh said to me.” Here the word “me” refers to Isaiah.

Quote: I will quietly observe from my home
Note: What God will observe can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “I will quietly observe that nation from my home” or “From my home, I will quietly watch what the people of that nation do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: like the simmering heat in sunshine, like a cloud of mist in the heat of harvest
Note: These phrases show how quietly God will watch the nation. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: Before the harvest
Note: This is a harvest of grapes. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “Before the grape harvest” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: when the blossoming is over
Note: It can be stated clearly that this refers to blossoms on grape vines. Alternate translation: “when flowers have finished growing on the grape vines” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: he will cut off the sprigs with pruning hooks
Note: Yahweh will cut off the branches before the grapes can ripen. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will cut off the branches with knives before their produce fruit” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: pruning hooks
Note: A pruning hook is a knife that people use to cut branches off of vines or other plants.

Quote: he will cut down and take away the spreading branches
Note: Yahweh will throw away the branches in judgment.

Quote: They will be left together
Note: God seems to change from telling the parable to speaking more directly about the nation. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “Those who are killed will be left together” or “Like branches that are cut off and thrown away, the bodies of those who are killed will be left on the ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parables]])

Quote: The birds will summer on them
Note: “The birds will eat them during the summer.” The word “birds” refers to birds that eat the flesh of dead bodies.

Quote: all the animals of the earth
Note: Alternate translation: “all kinds of wild animals”

Quote: will winter on them
Note: Alternate translation: “will eat them in the winter”

Quote: a people tall and smooth & a people feared far and near & a nation strong and trampling down, whose land the rivers divide
Note: These phrases all describe the people of one nation. See how you translated these phrases in [Isaiah 18:2](../18/02.md).

Quote: a people tall and smooth
Note: Alternate translation: “a people who are tall and have smooth skin”

Quote: a people feared far and near
Note: The words “far” and “near” are used together to mean “everywhere.” Alternate translation: “a people who are feared everywhere” or “a people that everyone in the earth fears” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

Quote: a nation strong and trampling down
Note: Trampling down represents conquering other nations. Alternate translation: “a nation that is strong and conquers other nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: to the place of the name of Yahweh of hosts, to Mount Zion
Note: The word “name” refers to Yahweh. Alternate translation: “to Mount Zion, where Yahweh of hosts dwells” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

# Isaiah 19 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in 19:1-18.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Egypt

This chapter prophesied destruction against the nation of Egypt. Their destruction will come from internal division instead of being conquered by another nation. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Imagery

Some of the imagery used in this chapter may be connected to the worship of specific false gods. One important god the people of Canaan worshiped was Baal, the god of rain or storms. One of the important gods the Egyptians worshiped was Ra, the god of the sun. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/falsegod]])

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### “In that day”
This changes the reference from the time when Assyria comes to dominate the world and looks to a more distant future day.

Quote: See
Note: Alternate translation: “Look” or “Listen” or “Pay attention to what I am about to tell you”

Quote: Yahweh rides on a swift cloud
Note: Yahweh seems to be pictured here as riding on a cloud as if he was riding in a chariot. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the idols of Egypt quake before him
Note: The idols are described as having feelings of fear as Yahweh approaches. Alternate translation: “the idols of Egypt tremble in fear before Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: the hearts of the Egyptians melt within themselves
Note: The heart melting represents losing their courage. Alternate translation: “the Egyptians have no more courage” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: a man against his neighbor
Note: The words “will fight” are understood from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “a man will fight against his neighbor” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: city will be against city
Note: The word “city” represents the people of the city. Alternate translation: “people of one city will fight against people of another city” or “people from different cities will fight against one another” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: kingdom against kingdom
Note: The words “will be” or “will fight” are understood from the previous phrases. Alternate translation: “kingdom will be against kingdom” or “kingdom will fight against kingdom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: kingdom against kingdom
Note: The word “kingdom” refers to a smaller kingdom within Egypt. It may also be called a province. It represents the people of that kingdom or province. Alternate translation: “the people of one province will be against the people of another province” or “people from different provinces will fight against one another” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: The spirit of Egypt will be weakened from within. I will destroy his advice
Note: The nation of Egypt is spoken of here as if it was a person. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: The spirit of Egypt will be weakened from within
Note: This can be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: “I will weaken the spirit of Egypt from within” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: I will destroy his advice, though they sought the advice of & spiritualists
Note: Alternate translation: “They sought the advice of … spiritualists, but that will do them no good. It will not stop me from destroying his advice”

Quote: I will destroy his advice
Note: This could mean: (1) Yahweh will cause the advice that he gives to be ineffective or (2) Yahweh will cause him to be unable to give any advice. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **advice**, you can express the same idea with the verb “advise.” Alternate translation: “I will confuse those who advise the king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: mediums & spiritualists
Note: These are people who claim to speak with those who have died.

Quote: I will give the Egyptians into the hand of a harsh master
Note: Here “hand” refers to power or control. Alternate translation: “I will give the Egyptians over to the control of a harsh master” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: this is the declaration of the Lord Yahweh of hosts
Note: Yahweh speaks of himself by name to express the certainty of what he is declaring. Translate as in [Isaiah 3:15](../03/15.md). Alternate translation: “this is what the Lord Yahweh of hosts has declared” or “this is what I, the Lord Yahweh of hosts, have declared” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

Quote: The waters of the sea will dry up, and the river will dry up and become empty
Note: Egyptians referred to the Nile River as “the sea.” These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: “The Nile River will completely dry up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: become foul
Note: Alternate translation: “become foul-smelling” or “stink”

Quote: will dwindle
Note: Alternate translation: “become smaller and smaller”

Quote: the reeds and flags will wither away
Note: Here, **reeds** and **flags** refer to two similar kinds of water plants. Alternate translation: “the plants along the river will die and decay”

Quote: every sown field beside the Nile
Note: Alternate translation: “the fields near the Nile where people have planted crops”

Quote: The fishermen will wail and mourn, and all who cast a hook into the Nile will mourn, and those who spread nets on the waters will grieve
Note: These three phrases mean basically the same thing. If necessary, the reason they will grieve can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “The fishermen who catch fish with hooks or nets will cry in despair because the fish in the Nile have died” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: cast a hook into the Nile
Note: In order to catch fish, some people put a little food on a hook, tie the hook to a string, and throw the hook into the water. When a fish tries to eat the food, its mouth gets stuck on the hook, and the person pulls the fish out of the water. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

Quote: cast
Note: throw

Quote: spread nets on the waters
Note: In order to catch fish, some people toss a net on the water. When fish get caught in it, they pull the net with the fish out of the water. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

Quote: The workers in combed flax
Note: Alternate translation: “Those who work with combed flax”

Quote: combed flax
Note: Flax is a plant that grows along the Nile River. People comb its fibers in order to separate them, and use them to make thread for linen cloth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

Quote: will turn pale
Note: Alternate translation: “will be ashamed”

Quote: The cloth workers of Egypt
Note: Alternate translation: “The people of Egypt who make cloth”

Quote: will be crushed
Note: Being crushed represents being discouraged. Alternate translation: “will be discouraged” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: work for hire
Note: Alternate translation: “work for pay”

Quote: will be grieved within themselves
Note: Alternate translation: “will feel very sad”

Quote: The princes of Zoan are completely foolish. The advice of the wisest advisors of Pharaoh has become senseless
Note: These two phrases are similar in meaning. Either the princes of Zoan are also the wisest advisors or Pharaoh, or they are another group of people that also are shown to be foolish. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Zoan
Note: This is a city in northern Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: How can you say to Pharaoh & kings?
Note: Isaiah uses a question to mock those in Egypt who claim to be wise. Alternate translation: “You foolishly say to Pharaoh … kings.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Where then are your wise men?
Note: Isaiah uses a question to mock the wise men. The word “your” refers to Pharaoh. Alternate translation: “You do not have any wise men.” or “Your wise men are fools.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Let them tell you and make known what Yahweh of hosts plans concerning Egypt
Note: Isaiah is implying that wise men should be able to understand God’s plans, but Isaiah does not really believe they are wise. Alternate translation: “If they were really wise, they would be able to tell you what Yahweh of hosts plans concerning Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])

Quote: they have made Egypt go astray, who are the cornerstones of her tribes
Note: The princes of Zoan and Memphis are spoken of as if they are the cornerstones of buildings because they are an important part of the community. Alternate translation: “the leaders have made Egypt go astray” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: princes of Zoan
Note: Zoan is a city in northern Egypt. See how you translated this in [Isaiah 19:11](../19/11.md).

Quote: Memphis
Note: This is a city in the northern part of Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: made Egypt go astray
Note: The word “Egypt” represents the people of Egypt. Going astray represents doing what is wrong. Alternate translation: “made the people of Egypt go astray” or “made the people of Egypt do what is wrong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Yahweh has mixed a spirit of distortion into her midst
Note: Isaiah speaks of Yahweh’s judgment as if Egypt was a cup of wine. He speaks of Yahweh causing the leaders’ thoughts to be distorted as if their distorted thoughts were a liquid that Yahweh mixed in with the wine. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has judged them by distorting their thoughts” or “Yahweh has judged Egypt by distorting its leaders’ thoughts, as intoxicating drinks confuse people’s thoughts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: distortion
Note: Alternate translation: “perverseness” or “confusion”

Quote: into her midst
Note: Here “her” refers to Egypt. Nations are sometimes spoken of as if they were women. Alternate translation: “within Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: they have led Egypt astray
Note: Here, “they” refers to the leaders described in the previous verses. The word “Egypt” represents the people of Egypt. Alternate translation: “the princes have led the people of Egypt astray” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: have led Egypt astray
Note: Leading people astray represents influencing them to do what is wrong. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: like a drunk staggering in his vomit
Note: Isaiah speaks of the people of Egypt doing what is wrong as if they were made to wander about like a drunken person. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: whether head or tail
Note: The “head,” the part of an animal a person would want to be, represents the leader. The “tail” is the opposite and represents people who follow. Alternate translation: “whether leader or follower” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: palm branch or reed
Note: The “palm branch” grows high on the tree and represents people who are wealthy and important. The “reed” grows in shallow water and represents people who are poor and unimportant. See how you translated similar phrases in [Isaiah 9:14](../09/14.md). Alternate translation: “whether they are important or unimportant” or “whether rich or poor” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Egyptians will be like women
Note: This emphasizes that the people of Egypt will be afraid and helpless when God punishes them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: because of the upraised hand of Yahweh of hosts that he raises over them
Note: Here “hand” refers to God’s power, and raising the hand against them represents punishing them. Alternate translation: “because Yahweh of hosts has raised his powerful hand to punish them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: The land of Judah will become a cause of staggering to Egypt
Note: The “land of Judah” and “Egypt” refer to the people in those places. The Egyptians will stagger because they are afraid. Alternate translation: “The people of Judah will cause the Egyptians to stagger” or “The people of Judah will cause the Egyptians to be terribly afraid” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Whenever anyone reminds them of her, they will be afraid
Note: Here, “them” and “they” refer to the Egyptians and “her” refers to the people of Judah. Alternate translation: “Whenever anyone reminds the Egyptians of the people of Judah, the Egyptians will be afraid”

Quote: there will be five cities in the land of Egypt that speak
Note: This refers to the people of those cities. Alternate translation: “the people in five Egyptian cities will speak” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: the language of Canaan
Note: This refers to Hebrew, the language of the people of God living in the land of Canaan. Here Canaan represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “the language of the people of Canaan” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: swear allegiance
Note: Alternate translation: “promise to be loyal”

Quote: One of these will be called
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. “People will call one of these cities” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: called The City of the Sun
Note: It is not clear whether the Hebrew word translated “Sun” here means “sun” or “destruction.” It is also not clear what the name tells us about the city. Alternate translation: “the city called Sun City” or “the city called Destruction City” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-textvariants]])

Quote: a stone pillar at the border to Yahweh
Note: The phrase “the border” refers to the border of Egypt. Alternate translation: “a stone pillar to Yahweh at the border of Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: It will be as a sign and a witness to Yahweh of hosts in the land of Egypt
Note: The abstract nouns “sign” and “witness” can be expressed with the verbs “show” and prove.” Alternate translation: “The altar will show and prove that Yahweh of hosts is in the land of Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: to Yahweh of hosts in the land of Egypt
Note: Yahweh being in the land of Egypt represents the people of Egypt worshiping him. Alternate translation: “that the people in the land of Egypt worship Yahweh of hosts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: When they cry
Note: Alternate translation: “When the Egyptians cry”

Quote: because of oppressors
Note: Alternate translation: “because people are treating them harshly” or “because others are causing them to suffer”

Quote: he will send them a savior and a defender
Note: Alternate translation: “Yahweh will send someone to save and defend the Egyptians”

Quote: he will deliver them
Note: Who Yahweh will deliver them from can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will deliver the Egyptians from their oppressors” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: Yahweh will become known to Egypt
Note: Here “Egypt” refers to the people of Egypt. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will make the people of Egypt know him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: will acknowledge Yahweh
Note: Alternate translation: “will accept the truth about Yahweh” or “will agree to the truth about Yahweh”

Quote: They will worship
Note: The object of their worship can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “They will worship Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: will make vows to Yahweh and fulfill them
Note: Alternate translation: “will make promises to Yahweh and keep them” or “they will make promises to Yahweh and they will do what they have promised to do”

Quote: Yahweh will afflict Egypt
Note: Here, “Egypt” refers to the people of Egypt. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will afflict the people of Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: afflict
Note: Alternate translation: “strike” or “punish”

Quote: afflicting and healing
Note: The word “them” is understood in this phrase. Alternate translation: “afflicting them and healing them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: afflicting and healing
Note: How this phrase relates to the phrase before it can be made clear with the words “after” and “also.” Alternate translation: “and after he afflicts them, he will also heal them”

Quote: there will be a highway
Note: A highway is a large road on which many people can travel.

Quote: the Assyrian will come
Note: “the Assyrian” refers to a person from Assyria, but represents anyone from Assyria who comes to Egypt. Alternate translation: “Assyrians will come” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-genericnoun]])

Quote: the Egyptian to Assyria
Note: The words “will come” are understood. Alternate translation: “the Egyptian will come to Assyria” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: the Egyptian
Note: This refers to a person from Egypt, but represents anyone from Egypt who comes to Assyria. Alternate translation: “Egyptians” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-genericnoun]])

Quote: the Egyptians will worship with the Assyrians
Note: The object of their worship can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “the Egyptians and Assyrians will worship Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: Israel will be the third with Egypt and Assyria
Note: The names of the three nations represent the people of those nations. Alternate translation: “the Israelites will be the third with the Egyptians and Assyrians” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: be the third with
Note: This could mean: (1) “join together with” or (2) “be the third blessing with” or (3) “be equal to.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])

Quote: Blessed be Egypt, my people; Assyria, the work of my hands; and Israel, my inheritance
Note: The names of the three nations refer to the people of those nations. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I have blessed you, people of Egypt, because you are my people; and I have blessed you, people of Assyria, because I created you; and I have blessed you, people of Israel, because I securely possess you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: the work of my hands
Note: Here “hands” refers to God’s power and action. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

# Isaiah 20 General Notes

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Naked and barefoot
This is an image used in this chapter to describe Assyria’s victory over Egypt and Ethiopia. While they will be defeated, they will not be totally destroyed. Instead, they will be left with nothing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Tartan
Note: the name of the chief commander of the armies of Assyria (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: Sargon
Note: the name of the king of Assyria

Quote: he fought against Ashdod and took it
Note: Ashdod refers to the army of Ashdod. Alternate translation: “he fought against the army of Ashdod and defeated it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: walking naked and barefoot
Note: “walking around without clothes and without sandals.” Here the word “naked” probably refers to wearing only his undergarments.

Quote: an omen
Note: Alternate translation: “a warning”

Quote: the king of Assyria will lead away the captives
Note: The king orders his army to do this task. Alternate translation: “the king of Assyria will have his army lead away the captives” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: will lead away the captives of Egypt, and the exiles of Cush
Note: It can be stated clearly that they will first attack and capture people. Alternate translation: “will attack Egypt and Cush and capture their people and lead them away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: to the shame of Egypt
Note: Egypt refers to the people of Egypt. Alternate translation: “which will bring shame on the people of Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: dismayed and ashamed
Note: Alternate translation: “afraid and put to shame”

Quote: because of Cush their hope and of Egypt their glory
Note: Hope and glory refer to their trust in the military power of these countries. Alternate translation: “because they had trusted in the power of the armies of Cush and Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: The inhabitants of these coasts
Note: the people who lived in the lands bordering the Mediterranean Sea

Quote: where we fled for help to be rescued
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “where we fled to so they would rescue us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: now, how can we escape?
Note: The author uses this question to emphasize how hopeless their situation was. Alternate translation: “now there is no way for us to escape!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

# Isaiah 21 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in 21:1-10, 13-17.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Cush
Dumah and Seir are places in Edom. Part of this chapter is a prophecy against Cush. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]])

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### The desert by the sea
This is a metaphor for an unknown nation. Scholars are divided over the proper identity of this nation, but it is probably Babylon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

### Mystery
The fulfillment of this chapter is very mysterious. It is unknown who is truly being addressed and how this is to be fulfilled in history. The translator should not attempt to give the reader insight into this prophecy’s fulfillment. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/fulfill]])

Quote: A declaration
Note: Alternate translation: “This is what Yahweh declares” or “This is Yahweh’s message”

Quote: about the desert by the sea
Note: This refers to the people who live in Babylon as being a desert, even though God has not made it into a desert yet. This event will certainly happen. Alternate translation: “about the people who live in a land that soon will be a desert” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pastforfuture]])

Quote: Like stormwinds sweeping through the Negev
Note: Isaiah compares the army that will attack the people to a storm with strong winds. They will be quick and powerful. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: from the wilderness
Note: Here “wilderness” refers to the wilderness of Judea. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: from a terrible land
Note: The army is from a people that cause great fear.

Quote: A distressing vision has been given to me
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh showed me a troubling vision” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: the treacherous man deals treacherously
Note: Alternate translation: “those who deceive will deceive”

Quote: the destroyer destroys
Note: Alternate translation: “those who destroy will destroy”

Quote: Go up and attack, Elam; besiege, Media
Note: In the vision given to Isaiah, Yahweh speaks to the armies of Elam and Media as if they are there listening to him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])

Quote: Go up and attack, Elam; besiege, Media
Note: It is understood that they are to attack the Babylonians. Alternate translation: “Go up and attack the Babylonians, you soldiers of Elam; go and besiege the Babylonians, you soldiers of Media” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: Elam & Media
Note: Here “Elam” and “Media” represent the soldiers from these places. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: I will stop all her groaning
Note: Here “her” represents all the people who are suffering because of the Babylonians. Yahweh will cause them to stop groaning when he sends the armies of Elam and Media to destroy the Babylonians. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: my loins are filled with pain
Note: The vision that Isaiah sees is so troubling it causes him physical pain. Here he describes the pain and cramping in the middle part of his body.

Quote: pains like the pains of a woman in labor have taken hold of me
Note: Isaiah compares his pain to the pain of a woman giving birth. This emphasizes the great pain he is feeling. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: I am bowed down by what I heard
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “What I heard has caused me to bend over in pain” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: I am disturbed by what I saw
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “what I saw has greatly troubled me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: My heart pounds; I shake with fear
Note: Alternate translation: “My heart beats fast and I am shaking”

Quote: They prepare
Note: Here “They” refers to the leaders of Babylon.

Quote: prepare the table
Note: Here “table” represents the food that people will eat at the feast. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: arise, princes
Note: Here “princes” refers in general to men with authority and not necessarily to sons of kings.

Quote: anoint your shields with oil
Note: Soldiers would put oil on their leather shields so they would stay soft and not crack during battle. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: post a watchman
Note: Alternate translation: “tell a watchman to stand on the wall of Jerusalem”

Quote: a chariot, a pair of horsemen
Note: Alternate translation: “a soldier riding in a chariot, a pair of horses pulling it”

Quote: Lord, on the watchtower I stand
Note: Here “Lord” refers to the person with authority that commanded the watchman to stand on the wall of Jerusalem.

Quote: Babylon has fallen, fallen
Note: Babylon being completely defeated by their enemies is spoken of as if Babylon has fallen. Here “Babylon” is a metonym that represents the people of Babylon. Alternate translation: “The people of Babylon are completely defeated” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: fallen, fallen
Note: The word “fallen” is repeated to emphasize that the people of Babylon were completely defeated by their enemies.

Quote: My threshed and winnowed ones, children of my threshing floor
Note: The people of Israel suffering because of the Babylonians is spoken of as if the people were grain that was threshed and winnowed. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: My threshed
Note: The word “my” refers to Isaiah.

Quote: Yahweh of hosts
Note: See how you translated this in [Isaiah 1:9](../01/09.md).

Quote: A declaration
Note: Alternate translation: “This is what Yahweh declares” or “This is a message from Yahweh”

Quote: about Dumah
Note: This is another name for Edom. Here “Dumah” represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “about the people of Dumah” or “about the people of Edom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: One calls to me
Note: Here “me” refers to Isaiah.

Quote: Seir
Note: This is the name of mountains west of Edom. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: Watchman, what is left of the night? Watchman, what is left of the night?
Note: This is repeated to emphasize that the person asking the question is worried and nervous. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: If you want to ask, then ask; and come back again
Note: Alternate translation: “Ask me now what you want to know, but also come back later and ask again”

Quote: A declaration
Note: Alternate translation: “This is what Yahweh declares” or “This is the message of Yahweh”

Quote: about Arabia
Note: Arabia refers to the population of Arabia. Alternate translation: “about the people of Arabia” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: In the wilderness of Arabia
Note: Arabia does not have a forest. Alternate translation: “Far off from the road in Arabia” or “Out in the bushes of Arabia” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: caravans
Note: a group of people traveling together

Quote: Dedanites
Note: This is a people group that lived in Arabia. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: land of Tema
Note: This is the name of a city in Arabia. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: fugitives
Note: A fugitive is a person who runs away so that his enemy will not capture him. See how you translated this in [Isaiah 15:5](../15/05.md).

Quote: with bread
Note: Here “bread” represents food in general. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: from the sword, from the drawn sword, from the bent bow
Note: Here “sword” and “bow” represents the soldiers who attack the inhabitants of Tema. Alternate translation: “from their enemies who attack them with swords and bows” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: from the weight of war
Note: The terror and suffering that is experienced during war is spoken of as if war were a heavy weight on people. Alternate translation: “from the horrors of war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: as a laborer hired for a year would see it
Note: “as a hired laborer would count the days of a year.” A hired worker is careful to count the days so that he works exactly the amount of time he is paid to work. This means Kedar will be defeated in exactly one year. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: of Kedar
Note: This is a region in Arabia. Kedar represents the population of Kedar. Alternate translation: “of the people of Kedar” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

# Isaiah 22 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Repentance
On this day of judgment, Judah should be repenting of their sin. Instead, they are celebrating it. Although Judah avoids Yahweh’s punishment through the Assyrians, their punishment will still come. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/judge]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/repent]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]])

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### “Valley of Visions”
This is a metaphor used in this prophecy against the nation of Judah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]])

Quote: A declaration
Note: Alternate translation: “This is what Yahweh declares” or “This is Yahweh’s message”

Quote: about the Valley of Vision
Note: Here “Valley” refers to those who live in the valley, that is, Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “about those who live in the Valley of Vision” or “about those who live in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: What is the reason that you have all gone up to the housetops?
Note: Isaiah uses a question to scold the people of Judah. Alternate translation: “You should not go and stand on the tops of your houses.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: a town full of revelry
Note: Alternate translation: “a town full of people celebrating”

Quote: Your dead were not killed with the sword
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Enemy soldiers did not kill your people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: with the sword
Note: Here “sword” represents the soldiers who fight in battle. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: but they were captured without using a bow
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “but the enemy captured your rulers who were not even carrying a bow” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: all of them were captured together
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the enemy captured all of them together” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Therefore I said
Note: Here “I” refers to Isaiah.

Quote: of the daughter of my people
Note: Here “daughter” represents the people and may imply Isaiah’s feeling of love for them. Alternate translation: “of my people whom I love” or “of my people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: For there is a day
Note: Alternate translation: “For there will be a time”

Quote: of tumult, treading down, and confusion for the Lord Yahweh of hosts
Note: Alternate translation: “when the Lord Yahweh of hosts will cause panic, treading down, and confusion”

Quote: treading down
Note: This could mean: (1) this refers to soldiers marching or (2) people in general are running in panic and not sure where to go.

Quote: in the Valley of Vision
Note: This refers to Jerusalem. See how you translated this in [Isaiah 22:1](../22/01.md).

Quote: people crying out to the mountains
Note: This could mean: (1) “people in the mountains will hear their cries” or (2) “the people’s cries will echo off the mountains”

Quote: Elam takes up the quiver
Note: The quiver is a bag to carry arrows and represents the archer’s weapons. Alternate translation: “The soldiers of Elam take their bows and arrows” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Kir lays the shield bare
Note: Here “Kir” represents the soldiers. Alternate translation: “the soldiers of Kir will take their shields out of their covers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Kir
Note: Kir is a city in Media. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: your choicest valleys
Note: Here “your” refers to the people of Jerusalem. Isaiah does include himself as one of the people of Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “our best valleys”

Quote: He took away the protection of Judah
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **protection**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will take away everything that has protected the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: you looked in that day to the weapons
Note: Here the phrase “to look to” means to trust in something. Alternate translation: “to defend yourselves you will get the weapons” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: Palace of the Forest
Note: This was a part of the temple in Jerusalem where they stored their weapons.

Quote: you collected the water of the lower pool
Note: The people will store water so that they will have enough to drink while their enemies surround the city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: You counted the houses
Note: Here “counted” means they inspected the houses to find material to help them rebuild the city wall.

Quote: You made a reservoir
Note: Alternate translation: “You made a storage place”

Quote: between the two walls
Note: It is unclear what two walls Isaiah meant. The main point is that they built the reservoir within the city walls.

Quote: the city’s maker
Note: This could mean: (1) this refers to the original human builder of the city or (2) this refers to Yahweh.

Quote: Yahweh of hosts
Note: See how you translated this in [Isaiah 1:9](../01/09.md).

Quote: for shaved heads
Note: This was a sign of mourning and repenting. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

Quote: let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we will die
Note: Here “eat and drink” represents having a party and over indulging in food and wine. Alternate translation: “we may as well have fun now by eating and drinking all we want, for we will die soon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: This was revealed in my ears by Yahweh of hosts
Note: Here “ears” represents Isaiah as a whole. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh of hosts revealed this to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Surely this iniquity will not be forgiven you, even when you die
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Surely I will not forgive you for these sinful things you have done, even when you die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: even when you die
Note: This could mean: (1) Yahweh will never forgive them, even after they die or (2) Yahweh will not forgive them until they die.

Quote: Shebna
Note: This is the name of the manager of the king’s palace in Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: who is over the house
Note: Here “house” represents those in the king’s palace. Alternate translation: “who is in charge of all those who work in the palace” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: What are you doing here and who gave you permission & in the rock?
Note: Yahweh uses this question to scold Shebna. Alternate translation: “You have no right … in the rock!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: cut out a tomb & hewing out a grave & carving out a resting place
Note: These three phrases all refer to making a burial tomb. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: on the heights
Note: The most important people in Israel had tombs in the highest places. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: He will surely wind you round and round, and toss you like a ball into a vast country
Note: The enemy soldiers coming and taking Shebna as a captive to a foreign land is spoken of as if Yahweh were throwing him like a ball into another land. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: you will be the shame of your master’s house
Note: Here “house” represents the people who work in the king’s palace. Alternate translation: “you will cause shame for all those in your master’s palace” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: I will thrust you from your office and from your station. You will be pulled down
Note: Yahweh causing Shebna to no longer work in the king’s palace is spoken of as if Yahweh will throw him to the ground. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: You will be pulled down
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will bring you down from your honored position” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: It will come about on that day
Note: Alternate translation: “It will happen at that time”

Quote: Eliakim & Hilkiah
Note: These are names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: I will clothe him with your tunic and put on him your sash
Note: Yahweh causing Eliakim to take Shebna’s place in the king’s palace is spoken of as if Yahweh will dress Eliakim in Shebna’s clothes that represent his authority in the king’s palace. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: your tunic & your sash
Note: Here the tunic and sash represent authority in the king’s palace. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: sash
Note: This is a piece of cloth that people wear around the waist or across the chest. See how you translated this in [Isaiah 3:20](../03/20.md).

Quote: into his hand
Note: Here “hand” represents power or control. Alternate translation: “to him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: He will be a father
Note: Eliakim caring for and protecting the people of Judah is spoken of as if he would be their father. Alternate translation: “He will be like a father” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: to the house of Judah
Note: Here “house” represents the people. Alternate translation: “to the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: I will place the key of the house of David on his shoulder & none will open
Note: Here “key” represents authority. This speaks of Eliakim having authority that no one can oppose as if he had the key to the palace and no one else could lock or unlock the door. Alternate translation: “I will put him in charge of those who work in the king’s palace, and when he makes a decision no one will be able to oppose him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I will fasten him, a peg in a secure place
Note: Yahweh causing Eliakim’s authority to be strong and secure in the king’s palace is spoken of as if Eliakim were a peg and Yahweh will set him firmly in the palace wall. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: he will become a seat of glory for his father’s house
Note: Here “seat of glory” represents a place of honor. Alternate translation: “Eliakim will bring honor to his family” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: his father’s house
Note: Here “house” represents family. Alternate translation: “his father’s family” or “his family” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: They will hang on him all the glory of his father’s house
Note: Yahweh causing Eliakim’s whole family to be honored because of Eliakim is spoken of as if Eliakim were a peg in the wall and his family were something that hangs on the peg. Alternate translation: “They will give honor to his whole family because of him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: every small container from the cups to all the jugs
Note: This continues to speak of Eliakim as a peg. His offspring will be like cups that hang on the peg. This means his descendants will be honored because of him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the cups to all the jugs
Note: A cup is a small container that holds water. A jug is a larger container that holds water.

Quote: the peg driven in a firm place & will be cut off
Note: Yahweh causing Shebna to lose his authority in the king’s palace is spoken of as if Shebna were a peg in the wall that breaks off and falls to the ground. This emphasizes that Shebna thought his authority was secure but God will remove him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the weight that was on it will be cut off
Note: Here “weight” represents Shebna’s power and authority. It is spoken of as if it were an object hanging on the peg that represents Shebna. Yahweh causing Shebna to lose his power and authority is spoken of as if someone were to cut off the object that was hanging on the peg. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Isaiah 23 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Phoenicia
This chapter prophesies destruction against several cities in Phoenicia as well as in Tarshish. The exact location of Tarshish is unknown. Because of the locations mentioned in this chapter, it appears that the Assyrians will conquer many of the nations on the Mediterranean Sea. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]])

Quote: A declaration about Tyre
Note: Alternate translation: “This is what Yahweh declares about Tyre”

Quote: Howl, you ships of Tarshish
Note: Here “ships” represents the men on the ships. Isaiah speaks to the men on the ships of Tarshish as if they could hear him. Alternate translation: “Cry out in despair you men on the ships of Tarshish” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])

Quote: harbor
Note: an area of the sea that is near land and safe for ships

Quote: from the land of Cyprus it has been revealed to them
Note: This phrase can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “the men heard about Tyre when they were in the land of Cyprus” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Be silent, you inhabitants of the coast
Note: Isaiah speaks to the people who live on the coast as if they could hear him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])

Quote: Be silent
Note: This is an idiom. Here silence is meant to signal shock and amazement. Alternate translation: “Be shocked” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: of the coast
Note: The “coast” is the land near or around the sea or ocean. Here it refers to the people who live in Phoenicia which borders the Mediterranean sea.

Quote: the merchant of Sidon, who travels over the sea, has filled you
Note: Here “merchant” means “many merchants.” Alternate translation: “the merchants of Sidon, who travel over the sea, have made you rich” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-genericnoun]])

Quote: Upon the great waters was the grain of Shihor
Note: Shihor was the name of a valley near the Nile River in Egypt known for its production of grain. Alternate translation: “The men traveled on the large sea to transport the grain from Shihor in Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: the harvest of the Nile was her produce
Note: The “harvest of the Nile” refers to the grain that was harvested near the Nile River and transported on the river and then to Phoenicia. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-possession]])

Quote: her produce
Note: Alternate translation: “its produce.” It was common to refer to the river as “her.”

Quote: it became the commerce of the nations
Note: Commerce is the activity of buying and selling goods. Here “nations” represents the people. Alternate translation: “you were where people from other nations came to buy and sell goods” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: for the sea has spoken, the mighty one of the sea & nor brought up young women
Note: This could mean: (1) Yahweh describes the city of Tyre as a mother who speaks about the people who live in the city as her children, or (2) Yahweh is describing the Mediterranean Sea as speaking. The people of Tyre considered the sea their god and father. In either meaning the speaker mourns because its children are destroyed. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: Cross over to Tarshish
Note: “Make your way to Tarshish.” Tarshish was the farthest land the people of Tyre traveled to do business. It will be the only place of safety for those who escape from Tyre.

Quote: Has this happened to you, the joyful city, whose origin is from ancient times & to settle?
Note: Yahweh uses a question to mock Tyre. This rhetorical questions can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: “This has indeed happened to you who were full of joy in the ancient city of Tyre … to settle.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: the joyful city
Note: Here “city” represents the people. Alternate translation: “the joyful people who live in the city of Tyre” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: whose feet carried her far away to foreign places to settle
Note: Here “feet” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “who went to distant places to live and make money” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: her far away
Note: Here “her” refers to the city of Tyre which represents the people of Tyre. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Who has planned this against Tyre & of the earth?
Note: Isaiah uses a question to mock Tyre. The word “this” refers to God’s plans to destroy Tyre which Isaiah described in 23:1-7. Also, “Tyre” refers to the people who live in Tyre. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “It was Yahweh who has planned to destroy the people of Tyre … of the earth.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: the giver of crowns
Note: Here “crown” refers to the power a person has as a ruler over people. Alternate translation: “who gives people power to rule over others” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: whose merchants are princes
Note: The merchants are compared to princes to emphasize how much power they had when they went to different lands. Alternate translation: “whose merchants are like princes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: whose traders are the honored ones of the earth
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “whose traders the people of the earth give the highest honors” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: to dishonor her pride and all her glory
Note: Alternate translation: “to dishonor them because they were proud of their own glory”

Quote: her pride & her glory & her honored ones
Note: Here “her” refers to the city of Tyre which represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “their pride … their glory … their honored one” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Plow your land, as one plows the Nile, daughter of Tarshish. There is no longer a marketplace in Tyre
Note: This could mean: (1) Isaiah is telling the people of Tarshish to start planting crops since they can no longer trade with Tyre or (2) Isaiah is telling the people of Tarshish they are free from Tyre’s control. Alternate translation: “Pass through your land like a river, daughter of Tarshish. The people of Tyre no longer have any power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: daughter of Tarshish
Note: The “daughter” of a city represents the people of the city. Alternate translation: “the people of Tarshish” or “the people who live in Tarshish” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Yahweh has reached out with his hand over the sea, and he has shaken the kingdoms
Note: Yahweh using his power to control the sea and the people of mighty kingdoms is spoken of as if Yahweh reached out his hand and shook kingdoms. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: has reached out with his hand over the sea
Note: Here “hand” refers to God’s power and control. Alternate translation: “has shown his power over the sea” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: oppressed virgin daughter of Sidon
Note: Here “virgin daughter” represents the people of Sidon. Alternate translation: “people of Sidon, because other people will oppress you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: See the land of the Chaldeans
Note: Here, **Chaldeans** here is another name for Babylonians. Alternate translation: “See what happened to the land of the Babylonians” or “See what has happened to Babylonia”

Quote: siege towers
Note: Soldiers built towers or dirt ramps to attack over the walls of a city.

Quote: Howl, you ships of Tarshish
Note: Here “ships” represents the men on the ships. See how you translated this in [Isaiah 23:1](../23/01.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: for your refuge has been destroyed
