Quote: the mountains will soak up their blood
Note: Alternate translation: “the mountains will be covered in their blood”

Quote: the sky will be rolled up like a scroll
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. This compares what Yahweh will do to the sky to a person rolling up a scroll. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will roll up the sky in the same way that a person rolls up a scroll” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: all their stars will fade away, as the leaf fades from off the vine, and as the overripe figs from the fig tree
Note: This emphasizes even the things in the sky that people thought would be there forever will fall as easily as a leaf. Alternate translation: “all the stars will fall from the sky like a leaf falls from a vine or a fig falls from a tree” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: when my sword will have drunk its fill in heaven
Note: Yahweh describes himself as a warrior bearing a sword. The phrase “drunk its fill” speaks of Yahweh’s sword as if it were a person who has eaten and become satisfied. Yahweh uses this imagery to emphasize that there will be a lot of destruction in heaven and to state its completion. Alternate translation: “when I am finished destroying things in heaven” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: look
Note: This word is used here to draw the listener’s attention and to have them imagine the things being said. Alternate translation: “listen” or “and then”

Quote: it will now come down on Edom, on the people I am setting apart for destruction
Note: The word “it” refers to Yahweh’s sword. This continues the metaphor about Yahweh destroying things with a sword. Alternate translation: “I will come to punish the people of Edom, the people whom I have set aside for me to destroy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: on Edom
Note: Edom refers to the people who live there. Alternate translation: “on the people of Edom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: The sword of Yahweh is dripping with blood and covered with fat & of rams
Note: This speaks of Yahweh killing the people as if he were a priest sacrificing animals. He does this by describing the sword of a priest. Alternate translation: “Yahweh sacrifices them as a priest sacrifices animals, whose sword drips with the blood and fat of lambs, goats, and rams” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: For Yahweh has a sacrifice in Bozrah and a great slaughter in the land of Edom
Note: The words “sacrifice” and “slaughter” may be expressed here as verbs. Alternate translation: “For Yahweh will sacrifice many people in Bozrah and kill many people in the land of Edom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: Bozrah
Note: This is an important city in Edom. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: will fall
Note: Alternate translation: “will die”

Quote: Their land will be drunk with blood
Note: This describes the amount of blood that will soak into the ground by comparing the land to a drunk person. Alternate translation: “Their land will be soaked with blood” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: their dust made fat with fatness
Note: Here “dust” means the dirt on the ground. This describes the amount of fat that will soak into the dirt by comparing it to a person that has become fat from eating so much animal fat. Alternate translation: “the dirt will be full of the fat of the animals” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: it will be a day of vengeance for Yahweh
Note: Here “day” is an idiom for a point in time; it is not a literal “day.” Alternate translation: “it will be the time when Yahweh gets revenge” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: he will pay them back for the cause of Zion
Note: This means that he will take revenge on them for how they had previously waged war against the people of Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “he will give them the punishment they deserve for what they had done to the people of Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: The streams of Edom will be turned into pitch & become burning pitch
Note: The water and land becoming useless for drinking or growing food because it is burnt and covered in pitch and sulfur is spoken of as if their streams and land will actually become pitch and sulfur. Alternate translation: “The streams in Edom will be full of pitch and the ground will be covered with burning sulfur and burning pitch” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: her dust & her land
Note: Alternate translation: “Edom’s dust … Edom’s land”

Quote: pitch
Note: a thick, black substance that burns for a long time

Quote: It will burn night and day
Note: This means all of the time. Alternate translation: “It will burn throughout the night and the day” or “It will burn constantly, all night and all day” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

Quote: from generation to generation
Note: The phrase “generation to generation” refers to all generations of people who will live in the future. See how you translated this phrase in [Isaiah 13:20](../13/20.md). Alternate translation: “forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: will live there
Note: Alternate translation: “will live in the land of Edom”

Quote: owl
Note: See how you translated this in [Isaiah 13:21](../13/21.md).

Quote: raven
Note: This is a large black bird. It is difficult to identify some of the precise kinds of birds mentioned in this passage. However, they were all birds that preferred to live in places where there were no people, so they symbolize deserted places.

Quote: in it
Note: “there.” This refers to Edom.

Quote: He will stretch over it the measuring line of ruin and the plumbline of destruction
Note: This speaks of Yahweh as if he were a careful builder as he causes destruction in Edom. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will measure that land carefully; he will measure it to decide where to cause ruin and destruction” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: measuring line & plumbline
Note: These are builders’ tools. See how you translated similar words in [Isaiah 28:17](../28/17.md).

Quote: Her nobles & her princes
Note: Alternate translation: “The nobles of Edom … the princes of Edom”

Quote: all her princes will be nothing
Note: This exaggerates the princes losing their royal status by saying that they will become nothing. Alternate translation: “all her princes will no longer rule” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])

Quote: Thorns & nettles & thistles
Note: These are all weeds with thorns. Nettles’ thorns have poison that causes itching.

Quote: jackals
Note: Translate the name of this animal the same as you did in [Isaiah 13:22](../13/22.md).

Quote: ostriches
Note: Translate the name of this animal the same as you did in [Isaiah 13:21](../13/21.md).

Quote: wild animals
Note: Translate this the same as you did in [Isaiah 13:21](../13/21.md).

Quote: hyenas
Note: Translate the name of this animal as you did in [Isaiah 13:22](../13/22.md).

Quote: Nocturnal animals
Note: animals that are awake and active at night

Quote: Owls
Note: Translate this word the same as you did in [Isaiah 13:21](../13/21.md).

Quote: hawks
Note: birds that kill small animals for food

Quote: Search through the scroll of Yahweh
Note: The phrase “the scroll of Yahweh” means that it contains the messages spoken by Yahweh. Alternate translation: “Read carefully what is written in this scroll that contains the messages of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-possession]])

Quote: not one of these
Note: Alternate translation: “not one of the animals”

Quote: None will lack for a mate
Note: This can be written as a positive statement. Alternate translation: “Each animal will have a mate” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])

Quote: for his mouth has commanded it
Note: Yahweh is referred to by his “mouth” to emphasize what he has said. Alternate translation: “for Yahweh has commanded it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: He has cast lots for their places
Note: This speaks of Yahweh deciding where to cause the animals to live as if he actually cast lots for their places. Alternate translation: “He has determined where they will live” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: his hand has measured it out for them by a cord
Note: This refers to the way that people measured things in biblical times. Alternate translation: “he has given the animals their places” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: from generation to generation they will
Note: The phrase “generation to generation” refers to all generations of people who will live in the future. See how you translated the phrase “from generation to generation” in [Isaiah 13:20](../13/20.md). Alternate translation: “forever they will” or “they will always” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

# Isaiah 35 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### Reign of the Messiah
This chapter appears to prophesy about a time of restoration when the Messiah will reign. It pictures a time of great peace and harmony in the world. The translator does not need to add an explanation, but should try to maintain the tense of the original text, as a future or uncompleted action. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/restore]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/christ]])

Quote: The wilderness and the Arabah will be glad; and the desert will rejoice
Note: These two phrases have basically the same meaning. These places are described as being glad, like a person is glad, because they have received water and are blossoming. Alternate translation: “It will be like the wilderness and the Arabah are glad and the desert will rejoice” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: blossom
Note: This speaks of the plants in the desert blossoming as if the desert itself were blossoming. Alternate translation: “its plants will blossom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: it will blossom abundantly
Note: This compares the way the plants of the desert blossom to the way a rose (verse 1) has many blossoms. Alternate translation: “The desert will grow many new plants and trees” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: and rejoice with joy and singing
Note: This speaks of the desert as if it were happy and singing like a person. Alternate translation: “it will be as though everything is rejoicing and singing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: the glory of Lebanon will be given to it
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. This speaks of Yahweh making the desert looks as glorious as Lebanon as if he were giving the desert Lebanon’s glory. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will give it the glory of Lebanon” or “Yahweh will make it as glorious as Lebanon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the splendor of Carmel and Sharon
Note: This speaks of Yahweh making the desert look beautiful as Carmel and Sharon as if he were giving the desert their splendor. The understood information may be supplied. Alternate translation: “the splendor of Carmel and Sharon will be given to it” or “Yahweh will make it as splendid as Carmel and Sharon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: the glory of Yahweh, the splendor of our God
Note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize Yahweh’s appearance. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: General Information:
Note: # General Information:\n\nIsaiah is speaking to the people of Judah.

Quote: Strengthen the weak hands, and steady the knees that shake.
Note: The words “weak hands” and “knees that shake” represent a person who is fearful. Alternate translation: “Strengthen those whose hands are weak and whose knees shake from fear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: those with a fearful heart
Note: Here people are referred to by their hearts, which emphasize their inner feelings. Alternate translation: “to those who are fearful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: Look
Note: This is used here to draw the listeners’ attention to what is said next. Alternate translation: “Listen”

Quote: your God will come with vengeance, with the recompense of God
Note: This can be reworded so that the abstract nouns “vengeance” and “recompense” are expressed as the verb “punish.” The words “vengeance” and “recompense” mean the same thing and emphasize that God will punish Judah’s enemies. Alternate translation: “your God will punish your enemies for what they have done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: General Information:
Note: # General Information:\n\nThese verses begin a description of the glorious future for God’s people.

Quote: the eyes of the blind will see
Note: “The blind” refers to people who are blind. They are referred to by their “eyes” to emphasize their healing. Alternate translation: “blind people will see” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: the ears of the deaf will hear
Note: “The deaf” refers to people who cannot hear. They are referred to by their “ears” to emphasize their healing. Alternate translation: “deaf people will hear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: the lame man will leap like a deer
Note: Deer can jump far and high. Jumping like a deer is an exaggeration for being able to move about quickly and easily. Alternate translation: “the lame man will jump high” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])

Quote: the mute tongue will sing
Note: This refers to people who cannot speak. They are referred to by their “tongues” to emphasize their healing. Alternate translation: “mute people will sing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: streams in the wilderness
Note: The understood verb may be supplied. Alternate translation: “streams will flow in the wilderness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: The burning sand will become a pool
Note: This means that a pool of water will appear in the hot sand. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “A pool will appear in the burning sand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: the thirsty ground
Note: Here the dry ground is described as being thirsty. Alternate translation: “the dry ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: the thirsty ground springs of water
Note: This means that springs will appear in the dry ground. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “springs of water will appear in the thirsty ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: jackals
Note: See how you translated this in [Isaiah 13:22](../13/22.md).

Quote: reeds and rushes
Note: These are plants that grow in wet areas.

Quote: General Information:
Note: # General Information:\n\nThese verses continue the description of the glorious future for God’s people.

Quote: A highway will be there called The Holy Way
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “A highway will be there that has the name The Holy Way” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: highway
Note: See how you translated this word in [Isaiah 11:16](../11/16.md).

Quote: The unclean
Note: This refers to unclean people. A person who God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. Alternate translation: “Those who are unclean” or “People who are not acceptable to God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: him who walks in it
Note: This is an idiom. Here “walking” refers to “living.” This refers to the person who lives a holy life. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “who lives in the holy way” or “who lives a holy life” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: they will not be found there
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “no one will find them there” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: the redeemed
Note: This refers to people who God has redeemed. Alternate translation: “those who are redeemed” or “those who God has redeemed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

Quote: The ransomed of Yahweh
Note: To “ransom” means to “rescue.” This refers to people whom Yahweh has rescued. Alternate translation: “Those whom Yahweh has rescued” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

Quote: everlasting joy will be on their heads
Note: This uses a person’s head to mean the person as a whole. Alternate translation: “they will have everlasting joy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: gladness and joy & sorrow and sighing
Note: The words “gladness” and “joy” mean basically the same thing, as do “sorrow” and “sighing.” Together they emphasize the intensity of these emotions. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: gladness and joy will overtake them
Note: This speaks of the people being overwhelmed by gladness and joy by giving these emotions the human quality of being able to overtake someone by force. Alternate translation: “they will be overwhelmed by joy and gladness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: sorrow and sighing will flee away
Note: This speaks of the people no longer being sorrowful and sighing by giving these emotions the human ability to run away. Alternate translation: “they will no longer be sorrowful and sighing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

# Isaiah 36 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

The previous chapters have been constructed as prophecy and contain many poetic elements. This chapter switches to a narrative and is a discussion between the officials from Assyria and Judah. To make the meaning clear here, it may be helpful to set apart the extended quotations by setting them farther to the right on the page than the rest of the text. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Trust

The people of Judah were to trust in Yahweh because only he could provide them with protection. The people of Jerusalem were protected because they trusted in Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/trust]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical Questions
The Assyrian commanders use rhetorical questions in this chapter to mock or insult Judah and their God, Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: the fourteenth year
Note: “year 14” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])

Quote: King Hezekiah
Note: See how you translated the name of this king in [Isaiah 1:1](../01/01.md).

Quote: Sennacherib
Note: This is the name of the king of Assyria. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: Sennacherib & attacked all the fortified cities
Note: Here Sennacherib represents himself and his army. Alternate translation: “Sennacherib and his army … attacked all the fortified cities” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: the chief commander
Note: Some versions of the Bible translate this as “the Rabshakeh.” This is the Assyrian word for one of the highest ranking military leaders in Assyria.

Quote: Lachish
Note: This is a city southwest of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: conduit
Note: man-made ditch or tunnel through which water flows. See how you translated this in [Isaiah 7:3](../07/03.md).

Quote: the launderers’ field
Note: This could mean: (1) this is the proper name by which the people called the field or (2) this is the common noun that the people used to talk about the field, “the launderers’ field” or “the field where men wash wool” or “the field where women wash clothes.” See how you translated this in [Isaiah 7:3](../07/03.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: the launderers’ field
Note: Here, **the launderers** are either: (1) men who wash wool that someone has cut from the sheep, “wool washers field,” or (2) women who wash dirty clothes, “clothes washers field.” See how you translated this in [Isaiah 7:3](../07/03.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: Hilkiah & Eliakim
Note: See how you translated these men’s names in [Isaiah 22:20](../22/20.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: Shebna
Note: See how you translated this man’s name in [Isaiah 22:15](../22/15.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: Asaph & Joah
Note: These are names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: said to them
Note: Alternate translation: “said to Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah”

Quote: What is the source of your confidence?
Note: The king of Assyria uses this question to challenge Hezekiah and to say that he does not have a good source for confidence. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You have no reliable source for your confidence.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: there is counsel and strength for war
Note: “you have the council and the strength to go to war.” The phrase “strength for war” refers to having a large enough and strong enough army with weapons. Alternate translation: “you have enough military council, strong men, and weapons to go to war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Now in whom are you trusting? Who has given you courage to rebel against me?
Note: The king of Assyria uses questions to ridicule Hezekiah for believing he has the strength to rebel. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “No matter in whom you trust, you will not have the courage to rebel against me.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Look
Note: Sennacherib uses this word to draw Hezekiah’s attention to what he says next. Alternate translation: “Listen”

Quote: trusting in Egypt
Note: Here “Egypt” refers to the Egyptian army. Alternate translation: “trusting in the Egyptian army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: that splintered reed that you use as a walking staff, but if a man leans on it, it will stick into his hand and pierce it
Note: This speaks of Egypt, specifically its army and its Pharaoh, as if it were a splintered reed to emphasize that relying on them would not help them but would only harm them. Alternate translation: “that is like walking with a splintered reed for a staff. If a man leans on it, it will stick into his hand and pierce it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: splintered reed
Note: A reed is the long, thin stem of a plant like tall grass. If it is splintered or damaged it cannot carry any weight.

Quote: walking staff
Note: This is a stick that someone would use for support when walking, made of whatever kind of tree limb that is found along the way.

Quote: is not he the one whose high places and altars Hezekiah has taken away & Jerusalem”?
Note: The king of Assyria uses this question to ridicule the people and to imply that Yahweh was angry about what Hezekiah did and would not protect them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “he is the one whose high places and altars Hezekiah has taken away … Jerusalem.” or “he is the one whom Hezekiah insulted by tearing down his high places and altars … Jerusalem.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: has said to Judah and to Jerusalem, “You must worship before this altar in Jerusalem”?
Note: This can be written as an indirect quote. “Judah” and “Jerusalem” refer to the people who live in them. Alternate translation: “has told the people of Judah and Jerusalem that they must worship only at this altar in Jerusalem.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-quotations]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: two thousand horses
Note: “2,000 horses” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])

Quote: if you are able to find riders for them
Note: The chief commander continues to ridicule Hezekiah and his army by implying that he did not have many soldiers. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])

Quote: How could you resist even one captain & servants?
Note: The chief commander continues to ridicule Hezekiah and his army. When he says “you,” referring to Hezekiah, he is actually referring to Hezekiah’s army. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Your army could not even defeat one captain … servants.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Now then, have I traveled up here without Yahweh to fight against this land and destroy it?
Note: The chief commander uses another question to ridicule Hezekiah and the people of Judah. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “I came here with Yahweh’s command to destroy Jerusalem.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: without Yahweh
Note: Here “Yahweh” refers to Yahweh’s orders. Alternate translation: “without Yahweh’s command” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: against this land and destroy it & Attack this land and destroy it
Note: This means to fight against the people and cause destruction in the place where they live. The land referred to here is Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “against this people and destroy their land … Attack these people and destroy their land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Eliakim & Hilkiah & Shebnah
Note: See how you translated these men’s names in [Isaiah 22:20](../22/20.md).

Quote: Shebnah
Note: See how you translated this man’s name in [Isaiah 22:15](../22/15.md).

Quote: Joah
Note: See how you translated this man’s name in [Isaiah 36:3](./03.md)

Quote: chief commander
Note: See how you translated this in [Isaiah 36:2](./02.md).

Quote: Please speak to your servants
Note: Eliakim, Shebnah, and Joah refer to themselves as the chief commander’s servants. This is a polite way to speak to someone who has greater authority.

Quote: the Aramean language, Aramaic
Note: “Aramean” is the name of a people group. “Aramaic” is the name of their language. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: in the ears of the people who are on the wall
Note: The idiom “to speak in someone’s ear” means to speak where they can hear you. Alternate translation: “where the people who are on the wall may hear us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: who are on the wall
Note: This means that they are standing on the wall. The top of the wall was wide and a place where people could sit or stand. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “who are standing on the wall” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: Has my master sent me to your master and to you to speak these words?
Note: The chief commander uses this question to emphasize that his message is for all the people of Judah. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Certainly, my master has sent me to speak this message to you and to all who can hear.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Has he not sent me to the men who sit on the wall, who will have to & you?
Note: The chief commander uses this question to emphasize his insult. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “My master has sent me to everyone who hears this, who will have to … you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: will have to eat their own dung and drink their own urine with you
Note: This is a very offensive statement. He is implying that they will need to eat these things because they will have nothing else to eat because their city will be under attack. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “will soon need to eat their own dung and drink their own urine, just as you will, because you will have nothing else to eat” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: the chief commander
Note: See how you translated this phrase in [Isaiah 36:2](../36/02.md).

Quote: this city will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will not give Jerusalem into the hand of the king of Assyria” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: the hand of the king
Note: The king’s “hand” refers to his “control.” Alternate translation: “the control of the king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Make peace with me
Note: This idiom means to agree officially to act peacefully towards one another. Alternate translation: “Let us agree to have peace” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: come out to me
Note: This idiom means to surrender. Alternate translation: “surrender to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: until I come and take
Note: Here the king of Assyria is referring to his army as himself. Alternate translation: “until my army comes and takes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: a land of grain and new wine, a land of bread and vineyards
Note: These two phrase have the same meaning and are used together to emphasize how prosperous the land will be. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: a land of grain & a land of bread
Note: This means that they land is full of natural resources, such as grain. Alternate translation: “a land where there is plenty of grain … a land where there is plenty of bread” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-possession]])

Quote: Has any of the gods of the peoples rescued them from & Assyria?
Note: The chief commander uses this question to ridicule the people of Judah. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “None of the gods of the peoples rescued them from … Assyria.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: the hand of the king
Note: The king’s control is referred to as his “hand.” Alternate translation: “the control of the king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim? Have they rescued Samaria from my power?
Note: The chief commander uses these questions to ridicule the people of Judah. These questions may be combined and written as a statement. Alternate translation: “The gods of Hamath, Arpad, Sepharvaim, and Samaria did not rescue their people from my power.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Hamath & Arpad
Note: Translate the names of these cities the same as you did in [Isaiah 10:9](../10/09.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: Sepharvaim
Note: This is the name of a city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: is there any god who has rescued & as if Yahweh could save Jerusalem from my power?
Note: The chief commander uses this question to ridicule the people of Judah. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “there is no god who has rescued … and Yahweh will not save you in Jerusalem from my power.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: his land
Note: This refers to the people who live in the land. Alternate translation: “his people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Eliakim & Hilkiah & Shebna & Joah & Asaph
Note: Translate the names of these men the same as you did in [Isaiah 36:3](../36/03.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: over the household
Note: This idiom means that he was in charge of the affairs of the palace household. Alternate translation: “in charge of the palace” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: with their clothes torn
Note: Hezekiah’s officials tore their clothes as a sign of mourning and distress. The meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: “with their clothes torn because they were extremely distressed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

# Isaiah 37 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in 37:22-38.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Tearing clothes and putting on sackcloth
This was a sign of great distress. While it is often accompanies repentance, in this chapter it is intended to show the king’s anger at the blasphemy of the Assyrians when they spoke against Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sign]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/repent]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/blasphemy]])

### Prayer
Hezekiah was different from the other kings because when he was threatened by Assyria, he went to Yahweh in prayer. He did not trust in his army or make an alliance with Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/trust]])

Quote: It came about that
Note: This phrase is used here to mark an important event in the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-newevent]])

Quote: he tore his clothes, covered himself with sackcloth
Note: This is a sign of mourning and distress. Alternate translation: “he tore his clothes and covered himself with sackcloth because he was very distressed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

Quote: Eliakim & Shebna
Note: Translate the names of these men the same as you did in [Isaiah 36:3](../36/03.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: over the household
Note: This is an idiom that means that he was in charge of the affairs of the palace household. Alternate translation: “in charge of the palace” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: all covered with sackcloth
Note: This is a sign of mourning and distress. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

Quote: They said to him
Note: Alternate translation: “The men sent by Hezekiah said to Isaiah”

Quote: like when a child is ready to be born, but the mother has no strength to give birth to her child
Note: This comparison is made to emphasizes that they are in a time of extreme difficulty. Alternate translation: “It is as terrible as the day when a child is ready to be born, but the mother has no strength to give birth to her child” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: It may be Yahweh your God will hear the words
Note: Hezekiah is indirectly suggesting that if the people pray Yahweh may listen and act upon what the chief commander had said. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “Maybe if you pray to Yahweh your God will hear the message” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: the chief commander
Note: See how you translated this phrase in [Isaiah 36:2](../36/02.md).

Quote: his master
Note: This phrase means that the king is the chief commander’s master.

Quote: will rebuke the words which Yahweh your God has heard
Note: Here the phrase “the words which Yahweh your God has heard” refers to what the king of Assyria had said. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “Yahweh your God will rebuke the king of Assyria for what he has said” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: lift up your prayer
Note: Praying to Yahweh is described this way to emphasize that Yahweh is in heaven. A prayer is spoken of as if they were objects that could be lifted high into the sky. Alternate translation: “pray” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: for the remnant that is still here
Note: This refers to the people who are left in Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “for the few of us that are still here” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: I will put a spirit in him, and he will hear a certain report and go back to his own land
Note: The phrase “put a spirit in him” means that God will influence him to make a specific decision. The word “spirit” here means a strong attitude or feeling. Alternate translation: “I will influence him so that when he hears a certain report, he will go back to his own land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: Look
Note: This word is used here to draw the peoples’ attention to what is said next. Alternate translation: “Listen”

Quote: I will cause him to fall by the sword in his own land
Note: The phrase “fall by the sword” is an idiom that means that his enemy will kill him with a sword. Alternate translation: “And there in his own land, I will cause his enemies to kill him with their swords” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: Lachish
Note: See how you translated the name of this city in [Isaiah 36:2](../36/02.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: Libnah
Note: This is a city in southern Judah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: Sennacherib
Note: See how you translated this man’s name in [Isaiah 36:1](../36/01.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: Tirhakah king of Cush and Egypt had mobilized to fight against him
Note: “Tirhakah” is the name of a man. He had mobilized his army so that they were ready to fight. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “Tirhakah king of Cush and Egypt had mobilized his army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: to fight against him
Note: The word “him” represents Sennacherib. Here Sennacherib represents his army. Alternate translation: “to fight against the army of Sennacherib” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Jerusalem will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. The word “hand” refers to the king’s military power. Alternate translation: “The king of Assyria and his army will not conquer you in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: See, you have heard
Note: The word “see” here is used to add emphasis to what is said next. Alternate translation: “You have certainly heard”

Quote: So will you be rescued?
Note: The king of Assyria uses this question to ridicule Hezekiah and his army. Alternate translation: “So you too will not be saved.” or “So of course no one will rescue you either!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Have the gods of the nations rescued them & Tel Assar?
Note: The king of Assyria uses this question to ridicule Hezekiah and his army. Alternate translation: “The nations’ god did not rescue the nations that my fathers destroyed … Tel Assar!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: that my fathers destroyed
Note: These men destroyed the cities listed by conquering them with their armies. Here the word “fathers” refers to his father and his other ancestors who were kings. Alternate translation: “that my fathers destroyed with their armies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: Gozan & Haran & Rezeph & Eden & Tel Assar
Note: These are places that the Assyrians had conquered. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: Hena & Ivvah
Note: These are places that the Assyrians had conquered. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: Where is the king & Ivvah?
Note: The king of Assyria uses this question to ridicule Hezekiah and his army. Alternate translation: “We also conquered the king … Ivvah!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Hamath & Arpad & Sepharvaim
Note: Translate the names of these cities the same as you did in [Isaiah 36:19](../36/19.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: from hand of the messengers
Note: Here the messengers are referred to by their “hand” to emphasize that they personally gave it to the king. Alternate translation: “that the messengers gave him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: he went up to the house of Yahweh
Note: The house of Yahweh was at the highest place in Jerusalem, so it is spoken of as “up.”

Quote: spread it before him
Note: “spread out the letter in front of Yahweh.” Being in the house of Yahweh is considered the same as being in Yahweh’s presence. The letter was a scroll that could be unrolled and spread out.

Quote: you who sit above the cherubim
Note: You may need to make explicit that the cherubim are those on the lid of the ark of the covenant. The biblical writers often spoke of the ark of the covenant as if it were Yahweh’s footstool upon which he rested his feet as he sat on his throne in heaven above. Alternate translation: “you who sit on your throne above the cherubim on the ark of the covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: you are God alone
Note: Alternate translation: “only you are God”

Quote: over all the kingdoms
Note: This idiom means to have authority and to rule over all the kingdoms. Alternate translation: “have authority over all the kingdoms” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: You made the heavens and the earth
Note: This means that he created everything. Alternate translation: “You made everything” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

Quote: which he has sent
Note: Hezekiah is referring to the letter from Sennacherib. The meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: “in the message he has sent” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: Turn your ear
Note: “Incline your ear” or “Turn your head.” This means to turn your head so that you can hear something better.

Quote: Sennacherib
Note: See how you translated this man’s name in [Isaiah 36:1](../36/01.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: all the nations and their lands
Note: This is a generalization. The kings had destroyed many of the nearby lands, but not necessarily all lands. Alternate translation: “many of the nations and their lands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])

Quote: for they were not gods but the work of men’s hands, just wood and stone
Note: This emphasizes that humans made these idols with their own hands and are therefore worthless. Alternate translation: “because they were false gods that men made out of wood and stone” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: from his power
Note: Alternate translation: “from the king of Assyria’s power”

Quote: all the kingdoms
Note: This refers to the people in the kingdoms. Alternate translation: “all the people in the kingdoms” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: you are Yahweh alone
Note: Alternate translation: “only you, Yahweh, are God”

Quote: sent a message
Note: This means that he sent a messenger to give a message to the king. Alternate translation: “sent someone to give a message” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: is the word that Yahweh has spoken
Note: Alternate translation: “is what Yahweh has said”

Quote: laughs you to scorn
Note: Alternate translation: “laughs at you” or “makes fun of you”

Quote: shakes her head
Note: This is a gesture of scorn. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

Quote: The virgin daughter of Zion & the daughter of Jerusalem
Note: These are idioms. Both of these phrases have the same meaning. The “daughter” of a city means the people who live in the city. See how you translated a similar phrase in [Isaiah 1:8](../01/08.md). Alternate translation: “The people of Zion … the people of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: Whom have you defied and insulted? & Against the Holy One of Israel.
Note: Yahweh uses these rhetorical questions to ridicule the king of Assyria. These can be written as statements. Alternate translation: “You have defied and insulted Yahweh, you have shouted at and acted pridefully against the Holy One of Israel!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: have you exalted your voice
Note: This refers to speaking loudly as if the person’s voice were an object that they lifted high. Alternate translation: “have you shouted” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: lifted up your eyes in pride
Note: This is an idiom that means to look at something pridefully, considering yourself more important that you should. Alternate translation: “looked at pridefully” or “acted pridefully” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: By your servants
Note: This refers to the servants that he had sent to Hezekiah with a message. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “In the messages you sent with your servants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: I have gone & I will cut & I will enter
Note: Here Sennacherib speaks of himself conquering many things. He is actually conquering them with the armies and chariots that he commands. Alternate translation: “We have gone … We will cut … we will enter” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: its tall cedars
Note: Alternate translation: “Lebanon’s tall cedars”

Quote: its most fruitful forest
Note: Here the word “fruitful” refers to the forest being dense and full of healthy trees. The understood information may be supplied. Alternate translation: “and into its most fruitful forest” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: I have dug & I dried & my feet
Note: Here Sennacherib speaks of himself conquering many things. He is actually conquering them with the armies and chariots that he commands. Alternate translation: “We have dug … we dried … our feet” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: I dried up all the rivers of Egypt under the soles of my feet
Note: Here Sennachrib is exaggerating his conquest and travels across the rivers of Egypt by claiming to have dried up the rivers when he marched his army through them. Alternate translation: “I have marched through all the rivers of Egypt as if they were dry under my feet” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])

Quote: Have you not heard how & times?
Note: Yahweh uses this rhetorical question to remind Sennacherib of information that he should already be aware of. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Certainly you have heard how … times.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: You are here to reduce impregnable cities into heaps of ruins
Note: Yahweh had planned for Sennacherib’s army to destroy the cities that they had destroyed. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “I planned that your army would destroy cities and cause them to become piles of rubble” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: impregnable
Note: strong and heavily guarded

Quote: I am bringing it to pass
Note: The idiom “to bring something to pass” means to cause a specific thing to happen. Alternate translation: “I am causing it to happen” or “I am causing these things to take place” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: of little strength
Note: Alternate translation: “who are weak”

Quote: shattered
Note: broken into small pieces. This is a metaphor for being greatly discouraged. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: They are plants in the field, green grass, the grass on the roof or in the field, before the east wind
Note: This speaks of how weak and vulnerable the cities are before the Assryian army by comparing the cities to grass. Alternate translation: “The cities are as weak as the grass in the fields before your armies. They are as weak as the grass that grows on the roofs of houses and is scorched by the hot east wind” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: before the east wind
Note: The east wind is hot and dry from the desert and plants die when it blows.

Quote: But I know your sitting down, your going out, your coming in
Note: This refers to all activities of life. Alternate translation: “I know everything you do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

Quote: and your raging against me
Note: The word “raging” can be expressed as a verb. Alternate translation: “how you rage against me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: your arrogance
Note: Here the king’s “arrogance” refers to his arrogant speech. Alternate translation: “your arrogant speech” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: your arrogance has reached my ears
Note: This speaks of Yahweh hearing the king’s speech as if the king’s speech were something that traveled to his ear. Alternate translation: “I have heard you speaking arrogantly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I will put my hook in your nose, and my bit in your mouth
Note: A person uses a hook and bit to lead an animal around. This speaks of Yahweh controlling the king as if the king were an animal Yahweh controlled with a bit and hook. Alternate translation: “I will control you like a man controls his animal by place a hook in its nose and a bit in its mouth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I will turn you back the way you came
Note: This refers to causing the king to return to his own home country. The meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: “I will force you to return to your own country” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: sign for you
Note: “sign for you, Hezekiah.” Here “you” is singular and refers to Hezekiah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])

Quote: you will eat & you must plant
Note: Here “you” is plural and refers to the people of Judah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])

Quote: in the second year what grows
Note: This describes what the people will eat. The words “you will eat” are understood from the previous phrase Alternate translation: “in the second year you will eat what grows” or “next year you will eat what grows” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])

Quote: what grows from that
Note: Alternate translation: “what grows wild from that” or “what grows wild”

Quote: in the third year
Note: This refers to the year after the second year. Alternate translation: “the year after that” or “in the following year” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])

Quote: remnant
Note: A “remnant” is a part of something that remains after the rest is gone. Here this refers to the people who are left in Judah.

Quote: the house of Judah
Note: Here Judah’s “house” refers to his descendants. Alternate translation: “the descendants of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: will again take root and bear fruit
Note: This speaks of the people of Judah becoming prosperous as if they were plants that would root and bear fruit. Alternate translation: “will prosper like a plant that takes root and produces fruit” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: For from Jerusalem a remnant will come out; from Mount Zion survivors will come
Note: These two phrases have the same meaning and are used together to emphasize the remnant of people who will survive. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: The zeal of Yahweh of hosts will do this
Note: This speaks of Yahweh doing something because of his zeal as if his “zeal” were actually doing the action. Alternate translation: “Because of his zeal, Yahweh of hosts will do this” or “Yahweh of hosts will do this because of his zeal” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: He will not come & He will not come
Note: Here the Assyrian king refers to both him and his army. Alternate translation: “His army will not come … They will not come” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: with shield
Note: Alternate translation: “with shields”

Quote: siege ramp
Note: a large mound of dirt built against the wall of a city that better enables an army to attach the city

Quote: he came & he will not enter
Note: Here the Assyrian king refers to both him and his army. Alternate translation: “they came … they will not enter” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: this is Yahweh’s declaration
Note: Yahweh speaks of himself by name to express the certainty of what he is declaring. Translate as in [Isaiah 30:1](../30/01.md). Alternate translation: “this is what Yahweh has declared” or “this is what I, Yahweh, have declared” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

Quote: for my own sake and for David my servant’s sake
Note: Alternate translation: “so that things will be better for me and for my servant David”

Quote: putting to death
Note: This idiom means to kill. Alternate translation: “killing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: 185,000 soldiers
Note: “one hundred and eighty-five thousand soldiers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])

Quote: Sennacherib king of Assyria left Israel and went home and stayed in Nineveh
Note: Here Sennacherib refers to both him and his army. They all left Israel and returned home to Assryia. Sennacherib returned to the city Nineveh. Alternate translation: “Sennacherib and his army left Israel and went home, and Sennacherib stayed in Nineveh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: Sennacherib
Note: See how you translated this man’s name in [Isaiah 36:1](../36/01.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: as he was worshiping
Note: Alternate translation: “as Sennacherib was worshiping”

Quote: Nisrok
Note: This is the name of a false god. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: Adrammelek & Sharezer & Esarhaddon
Note: These are the names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: with the sword
Note: Alternate translation: “with their swords”

# Isaiah 38 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in 38:10-20.

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### Poetry
This chapter is written as a narrative, but the section including Hezekiah’s prayer is written as poetry. The tone of this prayer shifts from sorrow to praise.

Quote: Set your house in order
Note: This means to prepare your family and those in charge of your affairs so that they know what to do after you die. This can be written clearly. Alternate translation: “You should tell the people in your palace what you want them to do after you die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: call to mind
Note: This idiom means to remember. Alternate translation: “remember” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: faithfully walked before you
Note: This is an idiom. Here “walk” means to “live.” The phrase means to live in a way the pleases Yahweh. Alternate translation: “faithfully lived before you” or “faithfully served you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: with my whole heart
Note: Here the “heart” refers to the inner-being which represents a person’s complete devotion. Alternate translation: “with all my inner being” or “with my complete devotion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: what was good in your sight
Note: The sight of Yahweh represents Yahweh’s judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: “what pleases you” or “what you consider to be good” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the word of Yahweh came
Note: This is an idiom that is used to introduce something that God told his prophets or his people. Alternate translation: “Yahweh spoke this message” or “Yahweh spoke these words” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: See
Note: This is used to ask the listener to pay attention to what is said next. Alternate translation: “Listen”

Quote: fifteen years
Note: “15 years” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])

Quote: the hand of the king of Assyria
Note: Here the king’s “hand” refers to his power. Alternate translation: “the power of the king of Assyria” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Look
Note: Yahweh uses this word to draw the listener’s attention to what is said next. Alternate translation: “Listen”

Quote: stairs of Ahaz
Note: These stairs are referred to this way because they were built while Ahaz was king. You can make this information clear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: that halfway through my life
Note: “that before I have grown old.” This refers to dying at middle age, before growing old.

Quote: I will go through the gates of Sheol
Note: This speaks of dying as if Sheol were a kingdom that has gates that one enters. Alternate translation: “I will die and go to Sheol” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I am sent there for the rest of my years
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “before I have lived all of my years I will go to the grave” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: in the land of the living
Note: “The living” refers to people who are alive. Alternate translation: “in the land where people are alive” or “in this world where people are alive” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

Quote: My life is removed and carried away from me like a shepherd’s tent
Note: This speaks of how Yahweh is ending Hezekiah’s life quickly by comparing it to how a shepherd removes his tent from the ground. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has taken my life away from me quickly like a shepherd packs up his tent and carries it away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: My life is removed
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has taken my life” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: I have rolled up my life like a weaver; you are cutting me off from the loom
Note: This speaks of Yahweh quickly ending Hezekiah’s life by comparing it to how a weaver cuts his cloth from the loom and rolls it up. Alternate translation: “you are ending my life quickly, like a weaver cuts his cloth from the loom when it is finished” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: you are cutting
Note: Here “you” is singular and refers to God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])

Quote: loom
Note: a device used to weave thread together to make cloth

Quote: like a lion he breaks all my bones
Note: Hezekiah speaks of how he is in extreme pain by comparing it to having his body torn apart by lions. Alternate translation: “my pain was as though I were being torn apart by lions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: Like a swallow I chirp; I coo like a dove
Note: Both of these clauses mean the same thing and they emphasize how sad and pitiful Hezekiah’s cries were. A swallow and a dove are types of birds. Alternate translation: “My cries are pitiful--they sound like the chirp of a swallow and the coo of a dove” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: my eyes
Note: Here Hezekiah refers to himself my his “eyes” to emphasize that he is looking for something. Alternate translation: “I” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: with looking upward
Note: This refers to Hezekiah looking to heaven for God to help him. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “of waiting for help to come from heaven” or “of waiting for you to help me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: I am oppressed
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “My sickness oppresses me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: What shall I say?
Note: Hezekiah uses a question to emphasize he has nothing left to say. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “I have nothing left to say.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: I will walk slowly
Note: This is an idiom. Here “walking” refers to living. Alternate translation: “I will like humbly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: all my years
Note: This refers to the rest of his life. The meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: “the rest of my life” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: because I am overcome with grief
Note: Alternate translation: “because I am full of grief” or “because I am very sad”

Quote: may my life be given back to me
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “may you give my life back to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: from the pit of destruction
Note: Hezekiah did not die but he was close to dying. This refers Yahweh saving him from dying. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “from dying and going to the pit of destruction” or “so that I did not die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: for you have thrown all my sins behind your back
Note: Hezekiah speaks of Yahweh forgiving his sins as if they were objects that Yahweh threw behind himself and forgot about. Alternate translation: “for you have forgiven all my sins and no longer think about them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: For Sheol does not thank you; death does not praise you
Note: Here “Sheol” and “death” refer to “dead people.” Alternate translation: “For those in Sheol do not thank you; dead people do not praise you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: those who go down into the pit
Note: Alternate translation: “those who go down to the grave”

Quote: do not hope in your trustworthiness
Note: “do not have hope in your faithfulness.” Here “your” is singular and refers to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])

Quote: The living person, the living person
Note: Hezekiah repeats this phrase to emphasize that only a living person, not a dead person, can give thanks to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: save me
Note: This refers to him being saved from dying. It can be made more explicit. Alternate translation: “save me from dying” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: we will celebrate
Note: Here “we” refers to Hezekiah and the people of Judah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])

Quote: Now
Note: This word is used here to mark a break in the main story line. This gives background information about Isaiah and Hezekiah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])

Quote: Let them
Note: Alternate translation: “Let Hezekiah’s servants”

Quote: a lump of figs
Note: This was used as an ointment. The meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: “use an ointment of mashed figs” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: boil
Note: a painful area on the skin that is infected

# Isaiah 39 General Notes

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Pride
Although it is not said why it was sinful for Hezekiah to show the king of Babylon his riches, the sin was probably because of his pride. It can be viewed as bragging to another king about how rich and powerful he was without giving proper credit to Yahweh. Because of this sin, Yahweh punished him. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

### Babylon
At this time, Babylon was not very powerful, but was little more than a city. In a short time, however, Babylon became a very powerful nation and conquered Assyria.

Quote: Marduk-Baladan & Baladan
Note: These are names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: Hezekiah was pleased by these things
Note: This can be made more explicit. Alternate translation: “When the king’s messengers arrived, Hezekiah was pleased with what they brought to him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: showed the messengers his storehouse of valuable things
Note: Alternate translation: “he showed the messengers everything of value he had”

Quote: storehouse
Note: a building where goods are kept

Quote: all that was found in his storehouses
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “everything that was in his storehouses” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: There was nothing in his house, nor in all his kingdom, that Hezekiah did not show them
Note: This is a slight exaggeration as Hezekiah showed them many things, but not everything. Also, this can be expressed positively. Alternate translation: “Hezekiah showed them almost everything in his house and in his kingdom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])

Quote: They have seen everything in my house. There is nothing among my valuable things that I have not shown them
Note: These two sentences mean the same thing and are used together to emphasize how much Hezekiah showed the men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: everything in my house
Note: This is a generalization, as Hezekiah showed them many things, but not necessarily everything in the palace. Alternate translation: “almost everything in my house” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])

Quote: There is nothing among my valuable things that I have not shown them
Note: This can be expressed positively. Alternate translation: “I showed them all the valuable things in my palace” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])

Quote: Yahweh of hosts
Note: See how you translated this phrase in [Isaiah 1:9](../01/09.md).

Quote: the word
Note: Alternate translation: “the message”

Quote: Look
Note: This word is used here to draw Hezekiah’s attention to what is said next. Alternate translation: “Listen”

Quote: when everything in your palace & will be carried to Babylon
Note: This can be expressed positively. Alternate translation: “when the enemy army will take everything in your palace … back to Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: The sons born from you
Note: Alternate translation: “Your sons”

Quote: they will take them
Note: Alternate translation: “the Babylonians will take them”

# Isaiah 40 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Rhetorical Questions
Yahweh uses many rhetorical questions in this chapter. These rhetorical questions help to prove the point he is making and convince the reader. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### “She has received double from Yahweh’s hand for all her sins”
It is common in many languages to use the feminine “she” to refer to a nation, rather than the word “it,” which is neither masculine or feminine. The translator should use the pronoun that aligns with the common usage in the target language. Therefore, it is acceptable to use “he,” “she,” or “it” in reference to a nation.

The phrase “received double” indicates that Jerusalem was punished more severely than the other nations. This is because they had the privilege of a special relationship to Yahweh and had more knowledge than the other nations.

### Reign of Yahweh
This chapter appears to prophesy about a time of restoration when the Messiah will reign. It pictures a time of great peace and harmony in the world. The translator does not need to add an explanation, but should try to maintain the tense of the original text, as a future or uncompleted action. It does not appear that this prophecy was fulfilled in the days of Isaiah. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/restore]], [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/christ]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/fulfill]])

Quote: Comfort, comfort
Note: The word “comfort” is repeated for emphasis.

Quote: says your God
Note: Here “your” is plural and refers to those whom the prophet tells to comfort God’s people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])

Quote: Speak tenderly to Jerusalem
Note: The prophet speaks of Jerusalem as if it were a woman whom Yahweh has forgiven. As such, Jerusalem represents the people who live in that city. Alternate translation: Speak tenderly to the people of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: proclaim to her & her warfare & her iniquity & she has received & her sins
Note: These pronouns refer to Jerusalem but may be changed if “the people of Jerusalem” is adopted as a translation. Alternate translation: “proclaim to them … their warfare … their iniquity … they have received … their sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

Quote: her warfare
Note: Possible meanings are that the word **warfare** refers: (1) to military battle or (2) to forced labor.

Quote: her iniquity is pardoned
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has pardoned her iniquity” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: from Yahweh’s hand
Note: Here the word “hand” represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “from Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: A voice cries out
Note: The word “voice” represents the person who cries out. Alternate translation: “Someone cries out” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: In the wilderness prepare the way of Yahweh; make straight in the Arabah a highway for our God
Note: These two lines are parallel and mean basically the same thing. The people preparing themselves for Yahweh’s help is spoken of as if they were to prepare roads for Yahweh to travel upon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Arabah
Note: See how you translated this word in [Isaiah 35:1](../35/01.md).

Quote: Every valley will be lifted up, and every mountain and hill will be leveled
Note: These phrases explain how the people are to prepare a highway for Yahweh. They can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “Lift up every valley, and level every mountain and hill” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Every valley will be lifted up
Note: Making the valleys level with the rest of the ground is spoken of as if it were lifting up the valleys. Alternate translation: “Every valley will be filled in” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: and the rugged land will be made level, and the rough places a plain
Note: These phrases explain how the people are to prepare a highway for Yahweh. They can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “make the rugged land level, and make the rough places into a plain” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: the glory of Yahweh will be revealed
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will reveal his glory” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: for the mouth of Yahweh has spoken it
Note: The word “mouth” represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “for Yahweh has spoken it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: All flesh is grass
Note: The word “flesh” refers to people. The speaker speaks of humans as if they are grass, because they both die quickly. Alternate translation: “All people are like grass” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: all their covenant faithfulness is like the flower of the field
Note: The speaker compares the covenant faithfulness of people to flowers that bloom and then die quickly. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “faithful.” See how you translated “covenant faithfulness” in [Isaiah 16:5](../16/05.md). Alternate translation: “they quickly stop being faithful to the covenant, just like a flower of the field dies quickly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: covenant faithfulness
Note: This could mean: (1) covenant faithfulness or (2) beauty.

Quote: when the breath of Yahweh blows on it
Note: This could mean: (1) “when Yahweh blows his breath on it” or (2) “when Yahweh sends a wind to blow on it.”

Quote: humanity is grass
Note: The speaker speaks of humans as if they are grass, because they both die quickly. Alternate translation: “people die as quickly as grass” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the word of our God will stand forever
Note: The speaker speaks of what God says lasting forever as if his word stands forever. Alternate translation: “the things that our God says will last forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Go up on a high mountain, Zion, bearer of good news
Note: The writer speaks of Zion as if it were a messenger who declares good news from a mountain top. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: Go up on a high mountain
Note: Messengers would often stand on elevated land, such as mountains, so that many people could hear what they proclaimed. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: Zion
Note: This refers to the people who live in Zion. Alternate translation: “you people of Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Jerusalem. You who bring good news
Note: The writer speaks of Jerusalem as if it were a messenger who declares good news. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: his strong arm rules for him
Note: Here the word “arm” represents God’s power. Alternate translation: “he rules with great power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: his reward is with him & those he has rescued go before him
Note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The ones he rescued are his “reward.” Alternate translation: “he is bringing those he rescued with him as his reward” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: He will feed his flock like a shepherd
Note: The writer speaks of Yahweh’s people as if they were sheep and of Yahweh as if he were their shepherd. Alternate translation: “He will care for his people like a shepherd feeds his flock” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Who has measured & or the hills in a balance?
Note: These rhetorical questions anticipate a negative answer and emphasize that only Yahweh is able to do these things. Alternate translation: “No one but Yahweh has measured … and the hills in a balance.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: measured the waters in the hollow of his hand
Note: Yahweh knowing how much water is in the oceans is spoken of as if Yahweh held the water in his hand. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: measured the sky with the span of his hand
Note: A “span” is the measure of length between the thumb and little finger when the hand is outstretched. Yahweh knowing the length of the sky is spoken of as if he measured it with his hand. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: held the dust of the earth in a basket
Note: Yahweh knowing how much dust there is on the earth is spoken of as if he carried it in a basket. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: weighed the mountains in scales, or the hills in a balance?
Note: Yahweh knowing how heavy the mountains are is spoken of as if he weighed them in scales and balances. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Who has comprehended the mind of Yahweh, or instructed him as his counselor?
Note: This rhetorical question anticipates a negative answer and emphasizes that no one is able to do these things. Alternate translation: “No one has comprehended the mind of Yahweh, and no one has instructed him as his counselor.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: comprehended the mind of Yahweh
Note: Here the word “mind” refers not only to Yahweh’s thoughts, but also to his desires and motivations.

Quote: From whom did he ever receive instruction?
