Note: Yahweh speaks of himself by name to express the certainty of what he is declaring. Translate as in [Isaiah 30:1](../30/01.md). Alternate translation: “this is what Yahweh has declared” or “this is what I, Yahweh, have declared” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

Quote: seeing that my people are taken away for nothing
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I see the enemy taking my people away for nothing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: for nothing
Note: This could mean: (1) “for nothing” means the Babylonians took the people unjustly and without cause or (2) this continues the metaphor from [Isaiah 52:3](../52/03.md) where Yahweh is spoken of as if he owned the people of Israel and could give them away for nothing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Those who rule over them mock
Note: This refers to the Babylonians who have conquered the people. However, some versions have, “Those who rule over them wail.” For these versions, this passage refers to the leaders of the Israelites in captivity.

Quote: my name is blasphemed continually all day long
Note: Here “name” represents Yahweh’s reputation. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “those who watch the enemy take away my people are continually saying evil things about me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Therefore my people will know my name
Note: Here “name” represents Yahweh’s reputation. Alternate translation: “Therefore my people will truly know who I am” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: General Information:
Note: # General Information:\n\nIsaiah is speaking to the people of Israel.

Quote: How beautiful on the mountains are the feet of the messenger who brings good news
Note: Here “feet” represents a messenger who is walking. Alternate translation: “It is beautiful to see a messenger coming over the mountains to announce good news” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: to Zion
Note: Here “Zion” represents the people of Zion. Alternate translation: “to the people of Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: raise their voices
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “shout loudly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: every eye of theirs
Note: Here “eye” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “every one of them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: you ruins of Jerusalem
Note: Isaiah speaks of the ruins of Jerusalem as if they were a person that could rejoice. This represents the people of Jerusalem who were defeated. Alternate translation: “you people who live among the ruins of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: he has redeemed Jerusalem
Note: Here “Jerusalem” represents the people. Alternate translation: “he has redeemed the people of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: bared his holy arm
Note: Here “arm” represents Yahweh’s power. Yahweh showing all the people of the nations that he is holy and powerful is spoken of as if Yahweh were a warrior who removed his cloak, baring his arms for battle. Alternate translation: “showed his holiness and mighty power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: all the nations; all the earth
Note: Here “nations” and “earth” represent the people of all the nations all over the earth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Leave, leave
Note: This word is repeated to emphasize that the people must indeed leave, although not necessarily right away.

Quote: go out from there
Note: It is assumed knowledge that the people of Israel were slaves in Babylon. This can be stated explicitly. Alternate translation: “go out from the land where you are slaves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: touch nothing unclean
Note: Something that Yahweh has stated is unfit to touch or eat is spoken of as if it were physically unclean. Alternate translation: “touch nothing that is unacceptable to Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: leave from her midst
Note: Here “her” represents Babylon.

Quote: Yahweh will go before you; and the God of Israel will be your rearguard
Note: Yahweh protecting his people from their enemies is spoken of as if he were the warriors who go ahead of the people and the warriors who stay behind the people to protect them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: he will be high and lifted up, and he will be exalted
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. These two phrases “high and lifted up” and “will be exalted” have basically the same meaning and emphasize that Yahweh will honor his servant. See how you translated a similar phrase in [Isaiah 33:10](../33/10.md). Alternate translation: “I will give my servant the greatest honor” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: his appearance was so disfigured beyond that of any man
Note: It is implied that the servant is disfigured because enemies beat him very badly. The full meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: “his enemies beat his body so badly that he did not even look like a human anymore” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: my servant will sprinkle many nations
Note: The servant causing the people of the nations to be acceptable to Yahweh is spoken of as if the servant were a priest who sprinkles the blood of a sacrifice to make someone or something acceptable to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: will sprinkle
Note: The Hebrew word translated “sprinkle” here can also be translated as “surprise” or “startle,” which some versions of the Bible do.

Quote: many nations
Note: Here “nations” represents the people of the nations. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: kings will shut their mouths
Note: The phrase “shut their mouths” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “kings will stop talking” or “kings will be silent” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: that which they had not been told
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “that which no one had told them” or “something no one had told them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

# Isaiah 53 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

In this chapter there is an important teaching or prophecy about the Messiah and his life and ministry. It begins in 52:13 and scholars usually note that it portrays the Messiah as a “suffering servant.” (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/christ]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Atonement
This chapter prophesies about the death of Christ for sin. Most scholars believe it teaches that Christ was a righteous man who died for the sins of mankind. This is usually referred to as the atonement. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/righteous]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/atonement]])

Quote: Who has believed what they heard from us
Note: What Isaiah just found out is so amazing that he wonders if the exiles will believe it. The “we” includes him and those in exile. Alternate translation: “It is hard for anyone to believe what we have heard” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: to whom has the arm of Yahweh been revealed?
Note: Arm refers to God’s power. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has revealed his power to people.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: For he grew up before Yahweh like a sapling
Note: Here “he” refers to God’s servant whom Isaiah compares to a very young tree. This emphasizes that he will appear weak. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: out of parched earth
Note: “parched earth” is hard and dry ground that will not allow plants to grow and represents where the servant of Yahweh will come. Alternate translation: “out of an impossible situation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: He was despised and rejected by people
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “People considered him as nothing and rejected him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: a man of sorrows
Note: Alternate translation: “a man knowing all kinds of sadness”

Quote: from whom men hide their faces
Note: “Face” represents a person’s attention or fellowship. Hiding one’s face means to turn away from someone. Alternate translation: “from whom people turn away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: he was despised
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “they considered him to be worthless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: he has borne our sicknesses and carried our sorrows
Note: To “bear” or carry an abstraction like sickness and sorrow represents taking it up. Alternate translation: “he has taken our sicknesses and sorrows upon himself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: yet we thought he was being punished by God, struck by God, and afflicted
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “yet we thought God was punishing and afflicting him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: But he was pierced because of our rebellious deeds; he was crushed because of our sins
Note: These two phrases share similar meanings and emphasize that the servant suffered because of the people’s sins. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God allowed the enemy to stab him and kill him because of our sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: The punishment for our peace was on him
Note: This refers to peace with God. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “He accepted this punishment so we could live in harmony” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: with his wounds we are healed
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “he healed us by his suffering of the wounds” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: We all like sheep have gone astray
Note: Sheep often leave the path on which the shepherd leads them. Isaiah means that we do what we want instead of what God commands. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: the iniquity of us all
Note: Our “iniquity” here represents the guilt for our sin. Alternate translation: “the guilt for the sin of every one of us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: He was oppressed
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “They treated him harshly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: he did not open his mouth
Note: “Mouth” represents what a person says. Opening one’s mouth means to speak. Alternate translation: “he did not protest” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: as a lamb that is led to the slaughter, and as a sheep that before its shearers is silent
Note: Isaiah compares the servant to a lamb and a sheep to emphasize that he will remain silent as people harm and humiliate him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: as a lamb that is led to the slaughter
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “just as a lamb is silent as a person slaughters it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: By coercion and judgment he was condemned
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “They treated him harshly, judged him, and condemned him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: coercion
Note: The Hebrew word translated here as “coercion” is interpreted by some versions as “arrest.” For these versions, the thought is that the Servant will be arrested and then judged and condemned.

Quote: who from that generation thought anymore about him?
Note: This question emphasizes that no one thinks about him. Alternate translation: “no one from his generation cared what happened to him.” or “no one among his contemporaries cared what happened to him.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: who from that generation thought anymore about him?
Note: Many versions interpret this passage in Hebrew differently: “Who can say anything about his descendants?” or “Who can say anything about his fate?”

Quote: But he was cut off from the land of the living
Note: “Cut off” here refers to death. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “But he died” or “But death took him away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: of my people
Note: Alternate translation: “of the people of Israel”

Quote: nor had there been any deceit in his mouth
Note: “Mouth” represents what a person says. Alternate translation: “nor did he deceive anyone when he spoke” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: he will see his offspring
Note: Here, “offspring” means those people that Yahweh has forgiven because of the servant’s sacrifice. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: he will prolong his days
Note: This speaks of making him live for more time. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will make his servant live again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: Yahweh’s purpose will be accomplished through him
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will accomplish his purpose through his servant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: After the suffering of his life
Note: Here “his life” refers to the servant. Alternate translation: “After the servant has suffered” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: he will see light
Note: Many versions understand “light” here to stand for life. That is, the servant will become alive again. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: My righteous servant
Note: Here “my” refers to Yahweh.

Quote: he will bear their iniquities
Note: The word “bear” means carry. This could mean: (1) “their iniquities” is a metonym representing the punishment for their sins. Alternate translation: “he will take their punishment” or “he will be punished for their sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])\n    * or (2) “their iniquities” is a metonym representing their guilt. Alternate translation: “he will take their guilt upon himself” or “he will be guilty for their sins”

Quote: Therefore will I give him his portion among the multitudes, and he will divide the spoils with the many
Note: These two clauses mean basically the same thing. “Portion” and “spoils” refer to a king after a victorious battle sharing the plunder or rewards with his army. This means God will greatly honor his servant because of his sacrifice. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the multitudes
Note: Many versions interpret this expression as “the many” or “the strong.”

Quote: because he exposed himself to death
Note: “Exposed” means to be vulnerable or unprotected. The servant of Yahweh put himself in a situation where he would die. Alternate translation: “he willingly accepted the possibility of death” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: was numbered with the transgressors
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “allowed people to treat him as a criminal” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

# Isaiah 54 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s covenant faithfulness
This chapter focuses on Yahweh’s faithfulness to fulfill his covenants. It references several different covenant promises in this chapter. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/covenantfaith]], [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/faithful]], [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/fulfill]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/covenant]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/promise]])

Quote: you barren woman & children of the married woman
Note: Yahweh telling the people of Jerusalem to rejoice because there will be many people living in Jerusalem again is spoken of as if Yahweh were telling a barren women she is going to have many children. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: break into joyful singing and cry aloud, you who have never been in birth labor
Note: This statement means the same thing as the first part of the sentence. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: For the children of the desolate one are more
Note: An event that will happen in the future is spoken of as if it happened in the past. This emphasizes that the event will certainly happen. Alternate translation: “For the children of the desolate woman will be more” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pastforfuture]])

Quote: the desolate one
Note: Here “desolate” means that the woman’s husband had rejected and abandoned her

Quote: Make your tent larger & strengthen your stakes
Note: This continues the metaphor that began in [Isaiah 54:1](../54/01.md). Yahweh telling the people of Jerusalem to prepare because Yahweh will greatly increase their people is spoken of as if he is telling a woman to make her tent bigger to make room for many children. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: For you will spread out
Note: Here “you” is singular and refers to the barren woman. She represents herself and all of her descendants. Alternate translation: “For you and your descendants will spread out” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: will conquer nations
Note: Here “nations” represents the people. Alternate translation: “will conquer the people of other nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: you will forget the shame of your youth and the disgrace of your abandonment
Note: Yahweh telling the people that in the future they will not even think about the shame they experienced when their enemies defeated them is spoken of as if Yahweh were telling a woman that she will no longer think about the shame she experienced from being unable to have children and having her husband abandon her. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: For your Maker is your husband
Note: Yahweh loving and taking care of his people is spoken of as if he were their husband. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Maker
Note: See how you translated this in [Isaiah 17:7](../17/07.md).

Quote: Yahweh of hosts
Note: See how you translated this in [Isaiah 1:24](../01/24.md).

Quote: The Holy One of Israel
Note: See how you translated this in [Isaiah 5:16](../05/16.md).

Quote: Redeemer
Note: See how you translated this in [Isaiah 41:14](../41/14.md).

Quote: he is called the God of the whole earth
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “he is the God of the whole earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Yahweh has called you back as a wife & like a woman married young and rejected
Note: Yahweh sending his people away into exile then bringing them back is spoken of as if Yahweh were a husband who had rejected his wife but now accepts her. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: grieved in spirit
Note: Here “spirit” represents a person’s inner being. Alternate translation: “grieved” or “made sad” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: In a flood of anger
Note: Yahweh being very angry is spoken of as if his anger were a flood that overwhelms people. Alternate translation: “When I was very angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I hid my face from you
Note: Here “hid my face” is an idiom that means God abandoned his people and let them suffer. Alternate translation: “I abandoned you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: but with everlasting covenant faithfulness
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “faithful.” See how you translated “covenant faithfulness” in [Isaiah 16:5](../16/05.md). Alternate translation: “but because I always am faithful to my covenant with you” or “but because I am always faithful to do what I promise to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: says Yahweh, the one who rescues you
Note: Here Yahweh speaks about himself in the third person. It can be stated in first person. Alternate translation: “that is what I, Yahweh, your rescuer, say to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

Quote: the waters of Noah
Note: This refers to the flood that Yahweh caused during the time of Noah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: Though the mountains may fall and the hills be shaken, yet my steadfast love
Note: Yahweh describes a hypothetical condition to explain what would happen even if those conditions were met. Alternate translation: “Even if the mountains fell and the hills shook, my steadfast love” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])

Quote: the hills be shaken
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the hills may shake” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: my steadfast love will not turn away from you
Note: Yahweh continuing to love his people is spoken of as if his love would not turn away from the people. Alternate translation: “I will not stop loving you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: nor will my covenant of peace be shaken
Note: Yahweh not canceling his covenant with the people is spoken of as if his covenant were an object that would not be shaken. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “and I will not cancel my covenant of peace” or “and I will surely give you peace as I promised in my covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: says Yahweh, who has mercy on you
Note: Here Yahweh speaks about himself in the third person. It can be stated in first person. Alternate translation: “that is what I, Yahweh, who acts mercifully, say” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

Quote: Afflicted one
Note: Here Yahweh speaks to the city of Jerusalem as if it were listening to him. Here Jerusalem represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “You afflicted people of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: storm-driven
Note: Yahweh speaks of the people as if they were blown around and damaged by the winds and storms. This means the people were hurt and without stability. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: uncomforted one
Note: Alternate translation: “without comfort”

Quote: I will set your pavement in turquoise & lay your foundations with sapphires
Note: Yahweh describes in ideal terms how he will restore Jerusalem and cause it to be beautiful again. Although the language may be exaggerated, you should translate this just as Yahweh described it.

Quote: turquoise & sapphires
Note: These are precious gemstones. Turquoise is light blue-to-green, sapphires are typically dark blue. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

Quote: I will make & beautiful stones
Note: Yahweh describes in ideal terms how he will restore Jerusalem and cause it to be beautiful again. Although the language may be exaggerated, you should translate this just as Yahweh described it.

Quote: rubies
Note: These precious gemstones are red to pink. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

Quote: Then all your children will be taught by Yahweh
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “And Yahweh will teach all your children” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: by Yahweh
Note: Yahweh speaks of himself in the third person. It can be stated in first person. Alternate translation: “by me, Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

Quote: In righteousness you will be established
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **righteousness**, you can express the same idea with an adjective such as “right.” If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will cause you to be strong again because you will do what is right” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: it will not come near to you
Note: No one in the city or outsiders will ever terrify the inhabitants of Jerusalem again.

Quote: General Information:
Note: # General Information:\n\nYahweh continue speaking to the people of Jerusalem.

Quote: stirs up trouble
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “causes trouble” or “troubles you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: will fall in defeat
Note: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “you will defeat them in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: No weapon that is formed against you will succeed
Note: Enemies not succeeding against Yahweh’s people is spoken of as if their weapons would not succeed against Yahweh’s people. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Enemies may form weapons to attack you but they will not defeat you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: This is the heritage of the servants of Yahweh
Note: The reward that Yahweh will give to those who serve him is spoken of as if the reward were something they would inherit. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: this is Yahweh’s declaration
Note: Yahweh speaks of himself by name to express the certainty of what he is declaring. Translate as in [Isaiah 30:1](../30/01.md). Alternate translation: “this is what Yahweh has declared” or “this is what I, Yahweh, have declared” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

# Isaiah 55 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Gentiles
Many scholars believe this chapter prophesies that Gentiles will be able to come to a saving faith in Yahweh. At this time, the Israelites believed that only an Israelite could be saved. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/save]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/faith]])

Quote: General Information:
Note: # General Information:\n\nYahweh speaks of blessing the people freely as if he were selling food and drink to needy people for free. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Connecting Statement:
Note: # Connecting Statement:\n\nYahweh continues speaking to the people of Jerusalem in exile through Isaiah.

Quote: Come & Come
Note: The repetition of this word four times adds a sense of urgency to the invitation.

Quote: buy wine and milk without money and without cost
Note: There is a sense of irony in this statement since a person usually has to use money to buy something. This emphasizes Yahweh’s amazing grace in giving these things freely. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])

Quote: Why do you weigh out & bread, and why do you labor & satisfy?
Note: Yahweh asks these questions to rebuke the people. He speaks of the people seeking happiness apart from Yahweh as if they were purchasing things to eat that were not food and working for things that could not satisfy them. Alternate translation: “You should not weigh out silver … bread, and you should not labor … satisfy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: weigh out silver
Note: This refers to counting silver coins in order to pay someone for something. Alternate translation: “pay money” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: for what is not bread
Note: Here the word “bread” represents food in general. It is implied that the people were buying things to eat that were not really food. Alternate translation: “for things to eat that are not really food” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: eat what is good, and delight yourselves in fatness
Note: The people trusting Yahweh for blessing and happiness is spoken of as if they are eating good food that is making them happy. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: in fatness
Note: The word “fatness” refers to meat that has plenty of fat on it and is an idiom for fine food. Alternate translation: “with the best foods” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: Turn your ears
Note: Listening to or paying attention to someone is spoken of as if it were turning one’s ears to someone. Alternate translation: “Pay attention” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: I have placed him
Note: This could mean: (1) this refers to what Yahweh did for King David in the past or (2) it refers to what God will do through one of David’s descendants.

Quote: the Holy One of Israel
Note: See how you translated this in [Isaiah 1:4](../01/04.md).

Quote: Seek Yahweh while he may be found
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Seek Yahweh while you can still find him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Let the wicked leave his path
Note: The word “wicked” refers to wicked people. Yahweh speaks of wicked people no longer sinning as if they were to stop walking along a path that they had been traveling. Alternate translation: “Let wicked people change the way they live” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the man of sin his thoughts
Note: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “let the sinful man leave his thoughts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: his thoughts
Note: This could mean: (1) “the way he thinks” or (2) “his plans”

Quote: he will pity him
Note: Alternate translation: “Yahweh will pity him”

Quote: to our God
Note: The verb may be supplied from the first phrase in this sentence. Alternate translation: “let him return to our God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: for as the heavens are higher than the earth, so are my ways higher than your ways, and my thoughts than your thoughts
Note: Yahweh speaks of the things that he does and how he thinks as being far superior to or higher than what people do and think, just like the sky is much higher than the earth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: For as the rain and snow & do not return there
Note: This is likely a description of the rain and snow evaporating.

Quote: so also my word & it will achieve the purpose for which I sent it
Note: Yahweh speaks of his word as if it were a person whom he sends out as his messenger to accomplish a task. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: my word will be that goes from my mouth
Note: Here the word “mouth” represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “the word that I speak” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: it will not return to me empty
Note: Here the description of the word returning to Yahweh means that it has completed the task that Yahweh had sent it to complete. That it will not return “empty” means that it will not fail to accomplish its task. Alternate translation: “it will not fail to complete its task” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: be led along peacefully
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will lead you along peacefully” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: the mountains and the hills will break out in joyful shouts before you, and all the trees of the fields will clap their hands
Note: Yahweh speaks of the mountains, hills, and trees as if they were people with voices and hands, celebrating as Yahweh rescues his people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: Instead of the thornbushes, the cypress will grow; and instead of the brier, the myrtle tree will grow
Note: The words “thornbushes” and “brier” refer to species of plants that have sharp thorns growing on them. The words “cypress” and “myrtle” refer to species of evergreen trees. The thorny plants symbolize desolation, while the evergreens symbolize life and prosperity. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])

Quote: for his name
Note: Here the word “name” represents Yahweh’s fame. Alternate translation: “for his fame” or “for his honor” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: that will not be cut off
Note: Something ceasing to exist is spoken of as if it were cut off, as a branch is cut off of a tree or a piece of fabric is cut off of clothing. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “that will never end” or “that will last forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

# Isaiah 56 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Gentiles
Many scholars believe this chapter prophesies that Gentiles will be able to come to a saving faith in Yahweh. At this time, the Israelites believed that only an Israelite could be saved. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/save]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/faith]])

## Important figures of speech in this chapter

### Beasts
The Israelites are compared to beasts and dogs in this chapter. This would have been very offensive to them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: for my salvation is near, and my righteousness is about to be revealed.
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will soon save you and show you that I am righteous” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: who holds it tightly
Note: Here “holds it tightly” is an idiom that means to continue to observe something. Alternate translation: “who is careful to always do this” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: keeps his hand from doing any evil
Note: Here the “hand” represents the whole person and emphasizes the person’s actions or behaviors. Alternate translation: “does not do evil things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: See, I am a dry tree
Note: This means eunuchs may have thought they could not be a part of God’s people because they were deformed by castration (and for this reason could not have children). Israelites did not practice castration; foreigners did, sometimes for punishment. Eunuchs who had accepted the Hebrew faith knew that normally they were not allowed to worship in the temple (Deut. 23:1). The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: in my house and within my walls
Note: These two phrases mean the same thing. Alternate translation: “inside the walls of my temple” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: that will never be cut off
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “that will never end” or “that will never be forgotten” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: who love the name of Yahweh
Note: Yahweh’s “name” represents himself. Alternate translation: “who love Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: holy mountain
Note: See how you translated this in [Isaiah 11:9](../11/09.md).

Quote: will be accepted on my altar
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will accept on my altar” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: my house will be called a house of prayer
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “my house will be a house of prayer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: All you wild beasts of the field, come and devour, all you beasts in the forest
Note: God is calling armies of other nations by comparing them to animals to come and attack the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: All their watchmen are blind
Note: This means Israel’s leaders cannot or perhaps do not want to see what is going on in society.

Quote: They are all silent dogs
Note: The leaders are supposed to open their mouths and warn the people, but they do not. Comparing someone to a dog in this society is a great insult. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: They dream, and lying down they love to sleep
Note: This means the leaders are not bringing God’s word of warning to Israel but prefer their own comfort.

Quote: The dogs have big appetites
Note: Yahweh continues comparing Israel’s bad leaders to dogs. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

# Isaiah 57 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Child sacrifice
This chapter references the killing of children. Some religions in the ancient Near East practiced the sacrificing of their children. This was considered evil by Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/evil]])

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### Mocking
The people abandoned the worship of Yahweh in favor of other gods. When they needed help, he tells them to ask these false gods. This is mocking the power of the false gods and shows the people the uselessness of their worship of these gods. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/falsegod]])

Quote: the people of covenant faithfulness
Note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “faithful.” See how you translated “covenant faithfulness” in [Isaiah 16:5](../16/05.md). Alternate translation: “the people who are faithful to the covenant” or “the people who are faithful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: are gathered away & is gathered away
Note: “die and go away … dies and goes away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])

Quote: that the righteous is gathered away from the evil
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “that the righteous people die, and Yahweh takes them away from all that is evil” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: He enters into peace
Note: Alternate translation: “The righteous enter into peace”

Quote: they rest
Note: they die (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])

Quote: those who walk in their uprightness
Note: Alternate translation: “those who have done what is right”

Quote: But come here
Note: God is calling all of the unfaithful people to come before him so he can judge them in a strong contrast to the promises for the righteous that came before.

Quote: sons of the sorceress
Note: This is a strong insult against the people who practice sorcery because sorcery and magic includes idolatry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: children of the adulterer and the woman who has prostituted herself
Note: This refers to actual and spiritual adultery. They have abandoned the worship of God and now worship other gods and idols along with actual prostitution in pagan Canaanite ceremonies.

Quote: Whom are you merrily mocking? Against whom are you opening the mouth and sticking out the tongue?
Note: Yahweh uses questions to scold the people who are mocking him through false worship. Alternate translation: “You are mocking me and making fun of me by opening your mouth wide and sticking out the tongue!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Are you not children of rebellion, children of deceit?
Note: Yahweh uses another question to scold the people. This does not refer to their birth but to their spiritual state. Alternate translation: “You are children of rebellion, children of deceit!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: You heat yourselves & under the rocky overhangs
Note: All of these actions are associated with worshiping idols. The oaks were sacred trees to the Canaanites. People thought such activity would increase fertility for people and the land. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: that have been assigned to you
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. The exact meaning in Hebrew is unclear. Alternate translation: “that is your lot” or “that is your inheritance” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: In these things should I take pleasure?
Note: Yahweh uses a question to scold the people. Alternate translation: “Certainly, these things do not please me.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: You prepared your bed
Note: This refers to sleeping with prostitutes as a part of worshiping false gods. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])

Quote: on a high mountain
Note: People often went on top of hills and mountains to worship false gods. They thought those were the best places for worship. This might even refer to Jerusalem, too. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: You made a covenant with them
Note: Alternate translation: “You made a contract with them”

Quote: you went down to Sheol
Note: The people did not literally go to Sheol, the world of the dead. Instead, Yahweh is indicating by exaggeration that the people were willing to go anywhere to find new gods to worship. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])

Quote: You found life in your hand
Note: After trying so hard, the idolators found they still had strength to keep going. Here “hand” equals “strength” or “capacity.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Whom are you worried about? Whom do you fear so much that has caused you to act so deceitfully & about me?
Note: Yahweh uses these questions to scold the people. Alternate translation: “You must really fear these idols for you to act so deceitfully … about me!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: so much that you would not remember me or think about me
Note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that, although the people should have remembered Yahweh, they did not. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

Quote: I will proclaim all your righteous acts and tell all that you have done
Note: Yahweh is being sarcastic, calling their evil deeds so-called righteousness. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])

Quote: let your collection of idols rescue you
Note: Yahweh is mocking the people and their idols. He tells the idols to save the people though he knows they cannot. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])

Quote: the wind will carry them all away, a breath will carry them all away
Note: This is saying the same thing in two ways to emphasize that idols are helpless and worthless. Alternate translation: “the wind, or even a breath, will blow them away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: holy mountain
Note: The “holy mountain” is Mount Zion, in Jerusalem. See how you translated this in [Isaiah 11:9](../11/09.md).

Quote: Build, build! Clear a way! Remove all the stumbling blocks from the path of my people
Note: Yahweh is emphatic and urgent that a clear and level road be available for the people to return to him and free of obstacles to worshiping Yahweh. This echoes [Isaiah 40:3](../40/03.md). (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: For this is what the high and elevated One says
Note: The words “high” and “elevated” have basically the same meaning here and emphasize Yahweh being exalted. See how you translated this in [Isaiah 6:1](../06/01.md) and [Isaiah 33:10](../33/10.md). See how you translated a similar phrase in [Isaiah 52:13](../52/13.md).

Quote: to revive the spirit of the humble ones, and to revive the heart of the contrite ones
Note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh will strengthen and encourage those who humble themselves before him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: spirit & heart
Note: Here these refer to a person’s thoughts and emotions, not the spirit and heart literally. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: I hid my face
Note: This means God gave up on his people and no longer helped or blessed them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: he went backward in the way of his heart
Note: This means the Israelites kept rejecting the true God for false ones. Here “backward” and “way” are location words representing motivations and feelings. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: his ways
Note: “their ways.” Here “his” refers to the people of Israel.

Quote: comfort and console those who mourn for him
Note: Alternate translation: “I will soothe and calm those who feel sad for the people’s suffering because of their sinful behavior”

Quote: I create the fruit of the lips
Note: Here “fruit of the lips” refers to what a person says. Alternate translation: “I cause them to praise and thank me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Peace, peace, to those who are far off
Note: “I have made peace with them who are far off.” The word “Peace” is repeated for emphasis.

Quote: But the wicked are like the tossing sea & mire and mud
Note: This compares the wicked to rough water on the shore that makes the water dirty. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

# Isaiah 58 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Fasting
The practice of fasting became more common after the exile. This was intended to bring people into a right relationship with God by creating a designated time to concentrate on him. It may have been believed that Yahweh heard people better when they fasted. The significance of fasting is derived from the faster’s attitude of repentance and faith in Yahweh and not the practice itself. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/repent]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/faith]])

## Other possible translation difficulties in this chapter

### “Yet they seek me daily”
The people did not truly seek Yahweh every day. They practiced the outward aspects of the Jewish religion, but their hearts were far from Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

Quote: Lift up your voice like a trumpet
Note: This means shout loudly. Here “your” refers to Isaiah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])

Quote: Confront my people with their rebellion, and the house of Jacob with their sins
Note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Together they strengthen the urgency to confront Yahweh’s people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: ‘Why have we fasted,’ they say, ‘but you do not see it? Why have we humbled ourselves, but you do not notice?’
Note: The people of Israel use questions to complain to God because they feel he is ignoring them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Look
Note: “Behold!” or “Pay attention.” Yahweh confronts their questioning by telling them to pay attention.

Quote: fist of wickedness
Note: “wicked fist.” This shows that they fight viciously. “Fist” represents anger that is physically violent. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Is this really the kind of fast that I would want & under himself?
Note: Yahweh uses a question to scold the people. They act like they are humble before God, but they are hurting other people. Alternate translation: “This is not the kind of fast I want … under himself.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: A day for anybody to humble himself, for him to bow down his head like a reed
Note: This means the person is bowing down, but he is not truly humble. “A reed” represents a weak plant that bends easily. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: Do you really call this a fast, a day that pleases Yahweh?
Note: Yahweh uses a question to scold the people. Alternate translation: “Surely you do not think this kind of fast pleases me!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: Is not this the fast that I choose & break every yoke?
Note: Yahweh uses a question to teach the people about the kind of fast that pleases him. Alternate translation: “This is the fast that I choose … break every yoke.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: To release wicked bonds, to undo the ropes of the yoke, to set the crushed ones free, and to break every yoke
Note: All of these phrases mean they should help those people whom the wicked are hurting and oppressing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Is it not to & your house?
Note: Yahweh uses another question to teach the people. Alternate translation: “It is to … your house.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Quote: break your bread
Note: This phrase represents starting the meal by the host tearing the loaf of bread apart. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

Quote: Then your light would be broken open like the sunrise
Note: “Break open” here is an idiom that means when a light begins to shine brightly. This means that if they help people in need, their deeds will be like lights others will see, as when the sun comes up after a dark night. Or the light may refer to the light of the Lord, shining on them and blessing them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: your healing would quickly sprout up
Note: This means God will bless and restore them quickly, as a wound heals quickly. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: your righteousness would go before you, and the glory of Yahweh would be your rearguard
Note: This refers to the time when God protected the people of Israel as they escaped from Egypt. This means God will again protect them from their enemies if they will do what is right.

Quote: your righteousness
Note: This expression in Hebrew can also be interpreted as the one who gives righteousness or even victory. In this context, this expression would refer to God. A few modern versions have this interpretation.

Quote: then your light will rise in the darkness, and your darkness will be like the noonday
Note: “Your light” represents the acts of kindness that will be examples to everyone, and the “darkness,” the bad deeds, will be overcome by their good deeds. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: satisfy you in regions where there is no water
Note: “Water” represents all they need for an abundant life even when their surroundings do not have enough. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: You will be like a watered garden
Note: “A watered garden” represents abundance and plenty so they will have all they need. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: like a spring of water, whose waters never fail
Note: “A spring of water” represents a source of abundance in a land where water is precious. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: you will be called
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “people will call you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: you turn back your feet from traveling on the Sabbath day, and from doing your own pleasure on my holy day
Note: Here the people are represented by their “feet.” God did not allow long travels or work on the day of rest. Alternate translation: “you stop traveling and doing what you want to do on the Sabbath, my holy day” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

Quote: I will make you ride on the heights of the earth
Note: This refers to God exalting the nation in reputation and power in response to living righteously. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: for the mouth of Yahweh has spoken
Note: The word “mouth” symbolizes what Yahweh says. Alternate translation: “for Yahweh has spoken it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

# Isaiah 59 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Yahweh’s deliverance
When Israel was conquered, they were being punished for their sin. Yahweh is strong enough to deliver them, but he did not because he desired to refine them through the experience of the exile. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/other/deliverer]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/sin]])

Quote: Look
Note: “Behold!” or “You should know!” Yahweh tells the people to pay attention.

Quote: Yahweh’s hand is not so short
Note: “Hand” represents power and ability. A “short” hand does not have power and ability. Alternate translation: “Yahweh is fully able” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: your & you
Note: These plural pronouns refer to the people of Israel as a single group. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])

Quote: your sins have made him hide his face from you
Note: “Face” represents being present and looking upon. Alternate translation: “your sins have made him turn away from you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: For your hands are stained with blood and your fingers with sin
Note: Here “hands” and “fingers” refers to their actions. This means they are guilty of doing violent and sinful things. “Your” is plural. Alternate translation: “For you have committed violent sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])

Quote: Your lips speak lies and your tongue speaks maliciously
Note: The parts of the body that make speech represent what people say. Alternate translation: “You speak lies and malicious things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: they conceive trouble and give birth to sin
Note: “Conceiving” and “giving birth” emphasize how carefully they plan to do sinful things. Here “they” still refers to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “they work hard to do sinful things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: They hatch eggs of a poisonous snake
Note: Eggs of a poisonous snake hatch into more dangerous snakes. “Poisonous snakes” represents evil the people do that harms more and more. Alternate translation: “They make evil that spreads out to make more evil” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: weave a spider’s web
Note: This represents the deeds of the people that are useless. Alternate translation: “produce things and activities that are useless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Whoever eats of their eggs dies, and if an egg is crushed, it hatches into a poisonous snake
Note: Eating a poisonous egg will kill the one that eats it and represents self-destruction. Breaking the egg allows the young poisonous snake to hatch and represents spreading destruction. Alternate translation: “The activities they do will destroy them and will spread destruction to others” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: if an egg is crushed
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “if someone crushes an egg” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Their webs cannot be used for garments, nor can they cover themselves with their works
Note: This means their sinful deeds cannot be covered and hidden, just as a web cannot serve as clothing and cover someone. Alternate translation: “Their evil deeds will be exposed as useless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Their webs cannot be used for garments
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “They cannot clothe themselves with their webs” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: deeds of violence are in their hands
Note: “Hands” represents the ability and power to do these things and therefore their responsibility. Alternate translation: “they are fully responsible for the violence they do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Their feet run to evil
Note: Here people are represented by their “feet.” This speaks of them doing something quickly as their feet running to it. Alternate translation: “They are quick to do evil things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: are their roads
Note: “roads” represents their way of life. Alternate translation: “are all they do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: there is no justice in their paths
Note: “paths” represents their way of life. Alternate translation: “they never do what is just” or “everything they do is unjust” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: They have made crooked paths
Note: “Crooked paths” represents the way of life that is corrupt. Alternate translation: “They say and do dishonest things. They are devious” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: justice is far from us
Note: Here “us” refers to Isaiah and the people of Israel. “Far” represents that justice is gone and difficult to get. Alternate translation: “justice is gone and very difficult to get” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: We wait for light, but see darkness; we look for brightness, but we walk in darkness
Note: Each of these phrases means that the people are waiting for God’s goodness, but it seems like he has abandoned them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: We grope for the wall like the blind & like dead men
Note: This means that because God is not coming to them, they feel helpless, not finding the right path and despairing of the future, with no hope for a vibrant life. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: We growl like bears and moan like doves
Note: These refer to the sounds the people made because they were distressed and mourning. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: our many transgressions
Note: Here “our” refers to Isaiah and the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])

Quote: before you
Note: Here “you” refers to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])

Quote: our sins testify against us
Note: Isaiah describes the sins as a person who goes before God to declare that the people are guilty. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: for our transgressions are with us
Note: “With us” represents being aware of them. Alternate translation: “for we are aware of our transgressions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Justice is driven back
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The people drive justice back” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Justice & righteousness & truth & right
Note: These are ideas that Isaiah describes as acting like persons. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: Trustworthiness
Note: Isaiah describes this idea as acting like a person. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: He saw that there was no man, and wondered that there was no one to intervene.
Note: Alternate translation: “Yahweh was appalled that no one came to help those who were suffering.” or “Yahweh was astonished that no one came to help those who were suffering.”

Quote: Therefore his own arm brought salvation for him
Note: Yahweh’s “arm” represents his ability and power. Alternate translation: “Yahweh used his own power to save the people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: his righteousness sustained him
Note: “Righteousness” here is a quality that acts like a person. The word can be translated as an adjective. Alternate translation: “he did right as he always would do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Quote: He put on righteousness as a breastplate and a helmet of salvation upon his head. He clothed himself with garments of vengeance and wore zeal as a mantle
Note: “breastplate,” “helmet,” “garments,” and “mantle” are clothing for war and fighting. Isaiah describes Yahweh as putting these on to punish his people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: mantle
Note: a loose, flowing robe

Quote: He repaid them
Note: Isaiah is describing a future event as if it happened in the past. This means that it will certainly happen.

Quote: fear the name of Yahweh
Note: Here “name” refers to Yahweh’s reputation and character. Alternate translation: “fear Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: from the west & from the sun’s rising
Note: Isaiah combines these words to mean people in all places of the world. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

Quote: for he will come as a rushing stream
Note: Narrow valleys in Judah were dry most of the year until a sudden, heavy rain turned them into fast-moving water. When that happened there was a lot of noise and wind. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: driven by the breath of Yahweh
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “which the breath of Yahweh drives” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: this is Yahweh’s declaration
Note: Yahweh speaks of himself by name to express the certainty of what he is declaring. Translate as in [Isaiah 30:1](../30/01.md). Alternate translation: “this is what Yahweh has declared” or “this is what I, Yahweh, have declared” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

Quote: my words which I have put in your mouth
Note: Alternate translation: “the message I have given you to speak”

# Isaiah 60 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Israel’s restoration
This chapter pictures a time when Israel will be fully restored to Yahweh. They will be everything Yahweh intended them to be. All the nations will look to Israel and acknowledge her special relationship to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/restore]])

Quote: Arise, shine; for your light has come, and the glory of Yahweh has risen on you
Note: This refers to the glorious things Yahweh has done for the inhabitants of Jerusalem. They are now to show that glory through what they do and say and have hope in the future. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: Though darkness will cover the earth, and thick darkness the nations
Note: Both of these phrases mean the same thing and are combined for emphasis. They refer to “spiritual darkness.” This means all the other people of the world will not know Yahweh or how to please him. This is a metaphor for divine judgment. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: yet Yahweh will arise upon you
Note: This means the light of God’s presence will appear for the people of Israel, and it will show the way they should go. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: his glory will be seen on you
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the people of the nations will see his glory on you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: General Information:
Note: # General Information:\n\nHere Yahweh begins speaking.

Quote: They all gather themselves
Note: “They” refers to the rest of the people of Israel who will come together to return to Jerusalem.

Quote: your daughters will be carried in their arms
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “they will carry your daughters in their arms” or “they will carry your daughters on their hips” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: Then you will look and be radiant, and your heart shall rejoice and overflow
Note: These phrases share similar meanings and emphasize that they will be very happy because of what will happen in Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: the abundance of the sea
Note: This refers to the riches and goods that will come to Jerusalem by way of shipping, perhaps from along the Mediterranean Sea.

Quote: be poured out to you
Note: This describes that the abundance will be like water that gushes out. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the dromedaries
Note: Alternate translation: “the young camels”

Quote: Ephah
Note: an area in Arabia (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: Kedar & Nebaioth
Note: These are the names of areas in Arabia. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

Quote: All the flocks of Kedar will be gathered together to you
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The people of Kedar will gather their flocks for you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: the rams of Nebaioth will serve your needs
Note: This refers to their need for sacrifices.

Quote: they will be acceptable offerings on my altar
Note: Alternate translation: “I, Yahweh, will accept them on my altar”

Quote: Who are these who fly along like a cloud, and like the doves to their shelters?
Note: Yahweh uses questions and poetic images to draw attention here. He compares the sails of the ships to clouds and doves. This is also a picture of the Israelites returning to the country where they belong. Alternate translation: “Look, I see something like clouds moving quickly and like doves returning to their shelters.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])

Quote: The coastlands
Note: This refers to the people who live on the coastlands and describes the area of coastlands as if it was people looking out. Alternate translation: “The people from the coastlands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: the ships of Tarshish
Note: This expression usually means large merchant ships suitable for long voyages.

Quote: Holy One of Israel
Note: See how you translated this in [Isaiah 1:4](../01/04.md).

Quote: he has honored you
Note: Alternate translation: “Yahweh has honored you, the people of Israel”

Quote: they will not be shut day or night
Note: Here “day” and “night” together mean “all the time.” If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “no one will ever shut them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])

Quote: so that the wealth of the nations may be brought, with their kings being led
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “so that the people of the nations may bring their wealth, along with their kings” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: those nations will be completely destroyed
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will completely destroy the people of those nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: The glory of Lebanon
Note: This refers to Lebanon being famous for its beautiful trees, especially cypress and cedar. The exact identification of all the trees is not known.

Quote: the place of my feet
Note: This refers to Yahweh’s temple. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: Holy One of Israel
Note: See how you translated this in [Isaiah 1:4](../01/04.md).

Quote: with no one passing through you
Note: Alternate translation: “with everyone avoiding your land” or “with all the foreigners avoiding your land”

Quote: You will also drink the milk of the nations, and will nurse at the breast of kings
Note: This refers to the wealth and plenty that will be drained from foreign nations. Both clauses repeat the same idea for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Redeemer
Note: See how you translated this in [Isaiah 41:14](../41/14.md).

Quote: the Mighty One of Jacob
Note: See how you translated this in [Isaiah 49:26](../49/26.md).

Quote: instead of wood, bronze, and instead of stones, iron
Note: Yahweh will give more valuable building materials to them now. Alternate translation: “instead of wood, I will bring bronze, and instead of stones, I will bring iron” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

Quote: I will appoint peace as your governors, and justice your rulers
Note: Yahweh describes “peace” and “justice” as human rulers. This means there will be complete peace and justice in the land of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])

Quote: Violence will no longer be heard in your land
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “There will no longer be reports of violence in your land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: but you will call your walls Salvation, and your gates Praise
Note: The physical objects have the names of spiritual qualities. The city of Jerusalem will be a safe place, and the people there will praise Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Quote: for Yahweh will be your everlasting light
Note: Both verses repeat this same idea for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: Your sun will no longer set, nor will your moon withdraw and disappear
Note: The moon will not literally disappear. This exaggeration is saying that the light of the sun and the moon will be much less bright than the light of Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])

Quote: the branch of my planting, the work of my hands
Note: These phrases mean approximately the same and are repeated for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: the branch of my planting
Note: Yahweh is comparing the people to young shoots coming up that he planted as if he was a gardener. Yahweh has placed his people in the land of Israel. This gives hope to the people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: the work of my hands
Note: Yahweh compares the people of Israel to something made by the skill of his handicraft. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Quote: that I may be glorified
Note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “so that all people may glorify me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

Quote: a thousand
Note: “1,000” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])

# Isaiah 61 General Notes

## Structure and formatting

Some translations set each line of poetry farther to the right than the rest of the text to make it easier to read. The ULT does this with the poetry in this chapter.

The first part of this chapter is probably a prophecy about the coming Messiah and not Isaiah because this was different than the message Isaiah delivered. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/christ]])

## Special concepts in this chapter

### Restoration
This chapter prophesies concerning a future time of peace and restoration. It is unlikely to have been fulfilled in Isaiah’s day. (See: [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/restore]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/prophet]] and [[rc://*/tw/dict/bible/kt/fulfill]])

Quote: The Spirit of the Lord Yahweh is on me
Note: “Spirit” here is the Holy Spirit of Yahweh who compels or motivates the person. See how you translated this in [Isaiah 11:2](../11/02.md) or in [Isaiah 42:1](../42/01.md).

Quote: the afflicted
Note: This refers to poor people, those in great sorrow, or oppressed people who have problems they cannot overcome by themselves.

Quote: liberty to the captives, and the opening of the prison for those who are bound
Note: These two phrases mean the same thing. They state that God will certainly give freedom to captives. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: the year of Yahweh’s favor, the day of vengeance
Note: Both of these phrases refer to the same span of time. “Year” and “day” are both specific examples that represent the greater whole. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Quote: year of Yahweh’s favor
Note: Alternate translation: “time when Yahweh will act kindly toward his people”

Quote: to give & to give
Note: Isaiah repeats this for emphasis.

Quote: a turban
Note: “a headdress” or “a beautiful head covering.” This is a long piece of cloth that is wrapped around the head.
